author: David Michael,"I love libraries! They are a great place to just hang out and be in touch with history and knowledge of the present and past. Often they offer classes and lectures and great places to study. And, sometimes the librarians are real cute as well! I use them differently today than in the past, however. I actually belong to several libraries now as a full time RVer so that I can access books on my Kindle. Yes! That most remarkable Amazon device that has allowed me to build my own library with nearly 1000 mostly free books in my Kindle Fire. At age 76, I look upon this as my personal treasury, a repositary of the wisdom of the ages. In summary, I think it's great that we have physical libraries as well as devices like the Kindle that allow us to access books from anywhere on the globe with relative ease. It's great that libraries have adapted and made changes in this computer age that benefit their surrounding communty. Bravo to libraries and librarians!",libraries,A1595-P,libraries,1,1,11529,7951616,"[[""love"", ""libraries""], [""great"", ""place"", ""hang"", ""touch"", ""history"", ""knowledge"", ""present"", Bill Manson,"The books, the computers, the storytimes, even the staff expertise are only elements of the emerging (or, more properly, continuing) role of the public library. The library is a community focal point and a community development agency. For decades, my colleagues in the field rode the wrong bus. Libraries and librarians sold themselves as information agents. Then we were blindsided by the development of do-it-yourself information tools. We forgot that our mandate is broader -- much broader -- than information. We are a place where people gather to connect to other people, to culture, to information, to works of art and works of the imagination. From an individual's perspective, that's enriching. From a community's perspective that's vital to the sustenance of vitality and diversity in the polity.",libraries,A1597-P,libraries,1,1,8970,7951620,"[[""books"", ""computers"", ""storytimes"", whisper spritely,"""Mental health professionals are, as a group, politically liberal and strong defenders of civil liberties, so initiating an action that is likely to curtail a person's civil liberties is contrary to their mindset."" The new 'stop and frisk': Mental health professionals wait until someone from out-of-town walks into the regular emergency room at Cornell Medical Center to have a legitimate and timely prescription for a controlled drug script filled. They police-escort the person across the hallway to the Psychiatric emergency room; force strip the person; ship the person to WestChester in-patient for six days against the person's will; taking all the regularly-prescribed medicine away while declaring the person bi-polar which the person is not;" Then tell the person they are free to find a way back to New York City
post: turning the person loose without the long-standing legitimate prescriptions. New York is receiving $8 Billion from the Federal Government to distribute to providers who the providers view as having a serious mental illness and/or substance abuse problem which could cause the person to harm him/herself or others. Good intentions veered very
label: A1569-P

author: rbirds,"This entire conversation gives me heartburn. I am a college teacher who, yes, has entries on Rate My Professor and who works for a college that overtly cites the website when lauding the success of its best teachers. So I pay attention to the public discussions of student evaluations. The heartburn comes not from fear that my rating index is too low but rather in the assumptions of both sides. The potential for abuse of these ratings is not based on students unqualified to evaluate their teachers (false, anyone can distinguish a poor product from a quality one) but rather on the methodology of Rate My Professor and other similar sites. As mentioned by at least one commenter, ratings suffer from selection bias and from a failure to use common terms. Those with strong opinions for or against are more likely to evaluate an instructor and what raters see as strict or smart or easy or dumb is so subjective that any two raters may have opposite definitions of the same word used in a rating. Not a good combination: an unrepresentative sample using uncommon terms to rate a product.",rate professors,A4747-P,rate professors,0,1,11705,16966922,"[[""entire"", ""conversation"", ""gives"", Kevin,"The President is right when he says the critics won't call it Obamacare once the ACA takes the path of Social Security and Medicare, meaning once it's implemented it will be wildly popular (despite protestations that the sky is falling) which is, of course, the root of the fear from the author, and the conservative camp in general, because, at that point, it will be impossible to reverse.",obamacare,A1453-P,obamacare,1,1,11815,10093840,"[[""president"", ""right"", ""says"", ""critics"", ""wo"", ""n't"", ""call"", ""obamacare"", ""aca"", ""takes"", ""path"", ""social"", ""security"", ""medicare"", ""meaning"", ""'s"", ""implemented"", ""wildly"", ""popular"", ""despite"", ""protestations"", ""sky"", ""falling"", ""course"", ""root"", ""fear"", ""author"", ""conservative"", ""camp"", ""general"", ""point"", ""impossible"", ""reverse""]]","[[""NNP"", ""JJ"", ""VBZ"", ""NNS"", ""MD"", ""RB"", ""VB"", ""NNP"", ""NN"", ""VBZ"", ""NN"", ""NNP"", ""NNP"", ""NNP"", ""VBG"", ""VBZ"", ""VBN"", ""RB"", ""JJ"", ""IN"", ""NNS"", ""NN"", ""VBG"", ""NN"", ""NN"", ""NN"", ""NN"", ""JJ"", ""NN"", ""JJ"", ""NN"", ""JJ"", ""VB""]]",president right says critics wo n't call obamacare aca takes path social security medicare meaning 's implemented wildly popular despite protestations sky falling course root fear author conservative camp general point impossible reverse,"[""obamacare""]",obamacare,1,1;;;;

Steelmen,"I appreciate the fact that the NYT moderates comments, even if it means mine don't go up for 12 or 18 hours. David J.Krupp,"Children are living, breathing and thinking human beings. They do NOT belong to their parents. They are entitled to the full protection of the law. If parents do things or fail to do things for their children that endanger their lives, the law should intervene. Parents should be charge with endangering the welfare of a child and child abuse. Liz Z,"I have two cats that were either given to me or purchased that were declawed. It is a sad situation since they do not climb and can only jump a short distance. They usually do not cover waste in their litter pans and well who would after having this done to them. My cats do not go outside due to having limited ability to protect or fight off an attacker. I would not have this procedure done to my other cats as it takes away their nature instinct to scratch things. Michael Keating,"After the cold war we reduced the number of agents, and the presence of the CIA. When 9/11 occurred we not only were caught very flat footed, but we did not have covert people on the ground and had to spend years putting that whole thing back together again. CAF,"This particular writing sums up a major problem men face: women feel free to ridicule manhood with the same asinine stereotypes (eg body odor and hair, calluses) that used to characterize the asinine stereotypes applied to women. anne,"Like most people my age, I was taught to write in cursive, and like most people today, I don't use it much. But I don't understand how anyone can have a distinctive signature (e.g., for writing checks, signing contracts) without cursive. Even many of the documents, such as invoices, that I send by e-mail, require a scanned signature. Elizabeth,"How about children who live in the district but attend private schools? Should they be allowed to play? What if their private school doesn't have a football team, or they don't make the team? Presumably their parents pay taxes;" should they get to try out for the public school team? Home-schooled children do NOT attend the school. It is a school team. They should not participate. Should home-schooled children get to participate in the spelling bee
post: robotics club
ori_id: public schools receive a certain amount of money for each child who enrolls
new_topic: not a lump sum based on how many parents pay taxes. These schools should not have to use their budgets to pay for opportunities for children who are not enrolled and
label: therefore
type_idx: do not bring dollars to pay for their education or other opportunities the school provides.""

Sam I Am,"""The Obama administration has only itself to blame for this mess - jamming the bill through Congress and ignoring warnings of these predictably disastrous results."" Hah! The Obama administration frittered away its time endlessly debating and proposing plans designed by Republicans in order to bring Republicans to the table. Predictably, they took up his offer to dither but refused to ultimately offer a single affirmative vote even though the plan is the Heritage Foundation's alternative to Hillary Clinton's proposal from the '90's. What Obama should have done is taken Medicare for All, jammed it through without dithering with an obstinate and mendacious bunch of saboteurs, and relished the political victory of delivering a wildly popular program. Instead, he dithered and ended up with a program that no one is willing to brag about.",obamacare,A4904-P,obamacare,0,1,2763,19586342,"[[""obama"", ""administration"", ""blame"", ""mess"", Dave T,"We created this problem ourselves in the way we've chosen to enforce current laws. The birth of an anchor baby should never have had any bearing on whether the parents are eligible to be deported. Once we caved in to the notion of 'keeping families together', we were doomed. I am all for keeping families together. If we send the parents home they can take their children with them. We need to make that clear up front.",birthright citizenship,A4205-P,birthright citizenship,0,1,10116,15881509,"[[""created"", ""problem"", ""way"", ""'ve"", ""chosen"", ""enforce"", ""current"", ""laws""], [""birth"", ""anchor"", ""baby"", ""never"", ""bearing"", ""whether"", ""parents"", ""eligible"", ""deported""], [""caved"", ""notion"", ""keeping"", ""families"", ""together"", ""doomed""], [""keeping"", ""families"", ""together""], [""send"", ""parents"", ""home"", ""take"", ""children""], [""need"", ""make"", ""clear"", ""front""]]","[[""VBD"", ""NN"", ""NN"", ""VB"", ""VBN"", ""VB"", ""JJ"", ""NNS""], [""NN"", ""NN"", ""NN"", ""RB"", ""NN"", ""IN"", ""NNS"", ""JJ"", ""VBN""], [""VBD"", ""NN"", ""VBG"", ""NNS"", ""RB"", ""VBN""], [""VBG"", ""NNS"", ""RB""], [""VBP"", ""NNS"", ""RB"", ""VB"", ""NNS""], [""VBP"", ""VB"", ""JJ"", ""RB""]]",created problem way 've chosen enforce current laws. birth anchor baby never bearing whether parents eligible deported. caved notion keeping families together doomed. keeping families together. send parents home take children. need make clear front,"[""birthright"", ""citizenship""]",birthright citizenship,1,0;;;;

Frank McNeil,"The author, in her zeal to protect the insurance companies from public wrath, has just made a splendid argument for Medicare for All. The Obama administration, naive in the extreme, though it had bought the support of Mark Bertolini and the other captains of the health insurance industry, when it had only rented them for a limited time. Now Mr. Bertolini, having failed in his effort to extort from the Justice Department a decision not to do its duty and raise anti-trust objections to AETNA's effort to create, through merger, a non-competitive insurance market, has taken his revenge on the American people. In view of the number of mergers sought and suspiciously similar requests for increases in ACA health care costs, perhaps the Justice Department should initiate an investigation of price fixing and collusion among health insurance companies. The writer, who fails to address the anti-trust issue, appears to favor Repeal and Don't Replace. How about ""Are There No Poor Houses?"" stephen g,"Besides agreeing with many of the critical comments here, I woul dadd that a fundamental problem is that the ratings never seem to go away--a bad rating in 2005 or 2007 is stiil there in 2015, though it may no longer have any relevance--either because the teacher has improved or simply moved on--and some of the comments can be very personal and stinging, bad enough in the short term but sickening to see present 10 years after the fact of teh class. Sequel,"The status quo ante prior to Obamacare was that healthcare was a complete perversion of the free market and open competition. This country allowed insurance companies to corner the market on healthcare via insurance, to price medical treatment beyond the range of any individual to pay without insurance, and therefore to deny care and coverage to anyone with impunity. Obama has restored the balance by taking away the insurance companies' ability to block consumers from receiving medical care. He did it without the social violence that, by rights, should have accompanied such a revolutionary change. Obama actually initiated a return of healthcare to a free market, competitive status. But it required an acknowledgement that basic healthcare is a right that cannot be abridged.",obamacare,A1470-P,obamacare,1,1,2750,10095919,"[[""status"", ""quo"", ""ante"", ""prior"", ""obamacare"", Sequel,"No one knows whether a ""real-looking"" name on a comment is authentic, nor do they agree on even what makes a name ""real-looking"". Furthermore, there is actually very little agreement on whether an idea is offensive merely because of the way it is expressed, or whether certain ideas should be considered so offensive that they may never be expressed in even the most cultivated verbiage. The writer's premise that anonymity produces bad ideas and vulgar expression appears highly doubtful. I submit that the quality of the idea being discussed is the only thing that matters, and that there will never be a consensus on that evaluation. If quality is too low (as in the bulk of what appears on Twitter), individuals are free to consider the idea poor or the manner of expression deficient. Openly airing all ideas still appears preferable to me to confining discourse to speakers who only express the right ideas, and who do so with a prescribed minimum of elegance. It's a superstition, but I'll stick with Justice Brandeis' axiom that ""sunshine is the best disinfectant.""",comment sections,A2773-P,comment sections,1,1,2776,18246960,"[[""one"", ""knows"", Mary O,"I find a lot of valuable information in the comments sections on the NYTimes. For the most part, the comments remain civil, and they are worth reading. Some commenters have even built up quite a following for their well-thought-out remarks. My Boston Globe subscription, not so much. The online comments are often vulgar and I usually don't bother reading them. Some of us aren't on social media -- I don't have a facebook or twitter account, and haven't seen the appeal of starting now. So the comment sections are still quite relevant to me!",comment sections,A2747-P,comment sections,1,1,14386,18246959,"[[""find"", ""lot"", ""valuable"", ""information"", ""comments"", ""sections"", ""nytimes""], [""part"", ""comments"", ""remain"", ""civil"", ""worth"", ""reading""], [""commenters"", ""even"", ""built"", ""quite"", ""following"", ""well"", ""thought"", ""remarks""], [""boston"", ""globe"", ""subscription"", ""much""], [""online"", ""comments"", ""often"", ""vulgar"", ""usually"", ""n't"", ""bother"", ""reading""], [""us"", ""n't"", ""social"", ""media"", ""--"", ""n't"", ""facebook"", ""twitter"", ""account"", ""n't"", ""seen"", ""appeal"", ""starting""], [""comment"", ""sections"", ""still"", ""quite"", ""relevant""]]","[[""VBP"", ""NN"", ""JJ"", ""NN"", ""NNS"", ""NNS"", ""NNPS""], [""NN"", ""NNS"", ""VBP"", ""JJ"", ""JJ"", ""VBG""], [""NNS"", ""RB"", ""VBN"", ""PDT"", ""NN"", ""RB"", ""VBN"", ""NNS""], [""NNP"", ""NNP"", ""NN"", ""JJ""], [""JJ"", ""NNS"", ""RB"", ""JJ"", ""RB"", ""RB"", ""VB"", ""VBG""], [""PRP"", ""RB"", ""JJ"", ""NNS"", "":"", ""RB"", ""NN"", ""NN"", ""NN"", ""RB"", ""VBN"", ""NN"", ""VBG""], [""NN"", ""NNS"", ""RB"", ""RB"", ""JJ""]]",find lot valuable information comments sections nytimes. part comments remain civil worth reading. commenters even built quite following well thought remarks. boston globe subscription much. online comments often vulgar usually n't bother reading. us n't social media -- n't facebook twitter account n't seen appeal starting. comment sections still quite relevant,"[""comment"", ""section""]",comment section,1,1;;;;

Kirtidev,"Although leaving Euro would be difficult, that seems to be the only way left for Greece. If they don't leave Euro, the ECB will never realize how important it is to maintain a country's infrastructure and tradition. As a currency Euro is a badly conceived currency. It has got the economic power but not the political power or control. As everyone knows, economic power without political power is like putting the cart before the horse. It frustrates everyone and ends up into a blame game. w.f.murray,"I think our, so called, entertainment industry is conditioning our young to more violence and radical behavior. In the case of all irrational behavior... More aggressive action must be taken when family or authorities see unusual behavior. In this case his parents recognized his problems, had concern, and notified law enforcement. The sad thing is he conned law enforcement and they took no action at all. In this case he should have been forced to seek professional help. Gene S.,Reasonable public health measures must not be subjected to religious exemption. The measles problem in California is the direct result of permitting parents to opt out of vaccinations for religious reasons or because of reliance on long-disproved flawed medical studies. A parent should not have the right to insist that their child be permitted to be a potential carrier of a dangerous communicable disease. W.A. Spitzer,"Let me begin by saying that I grew up in farm country (cash grain - corn/soybeans) and I own farm land and annually receive farm subsidy payments. I would make a few points. First, most of the people who expound about farmers and farming have no idea what they are talking about. Second, I have heard about giant farms who receive huge subsidies all my life, so I presume it must be true, but it simply doesn't exist in the corn/soybean area I am familiar with. Third, there have been dramatic boom/bust cycles in crop prices the past few years, but this has been driven by speculators in the commodities markets, and currency manipulation (China). Fourth, farm products such as corn and soybeans are one of the few items that this country still exports in large amounts, so you had better be careful what you do. Finally, having said that, there has not been a recession in farm country - the farmers are doing quite nicely, and there is no reason that crop payments for corn and soybeans should continue.",farm Jack Robinson,"Comments are a useful and frequently informative part of online news;" they should be encouraged but much more closely monitored. For openers
post: commenters should be allowed only one comment per article to avoid these ubiquitous back and forth
ori_topic: witless arguments which often clog the comments section. Obscene
ori_id: vulgar and personal attacks should be edited out
new_topic: but care must be exercised. Many subjects almost demand strong comments which some may find offensive
label: but do not really cross the line. Some are clearly at the far left
text: but important points of view. In addition
pos_text: many articles and editorials contain claims that are either wrong or at best distorted
text_s: despite usually high standards of editorial review. Comments are essential for correcting these problems. Some blogs
topic: like Prof Juan Cole usually contain thoughtful
topic_str: informed and useful information. Others seem to call forth the the worst forms of trolls
column17: I believe can correct the abuses and allow a very important part of the internet to thrive.""
column245: comments useful frequently informative part online news encouraged much closely monitored. openers commenters allowed one comment per article avoid ubiquitous back forth witless arguments often clog comments section. obscene vulgar personal attacks edited care must exercised. many subjects almost demand strong comments may find offensive really cross line. clearly far left right extreme often bring ignored important points view. addition many articles editorials contain claims either wrong best distorted despite usually high standards editorial review. comments essential correcting problems. blogs like prof juan cole usually contain thoughtful informed useful information. others seem call forth worst forms trolls bullys idiots haters. proper monitoring believe correct abuses allow important part internet thrive

fancynancy93,"I would think it would depend on the individual student. My son and my grandson have both taken courses on-line and have done very well!! Perhaps as there are less distractions, working at their own pace and on a time when they are more receptive to learning. They might miss the interaction physically..but...the plus outweighs the minisus. MJT,"The drug war and racism started this war. Throw in the media, movies, self serving prosecutors, politicians, and welcome to America. There are too many police. Fueled by public fear, all these agencies are bleeding us dry and emptying our wallets. We spend trillions on healthcare, and probably our greatest health issue is handed over to the police to solve. Talk about the dark ages. Clean up the drug issue and shrink the police.",police,A4459-P,police,0,1,15063,14660940,"[[""drug"", ""war"", ""racism"", ""started"", ""war""], [""throw"", ""media"", ""movies"", ""self"", ""serving"", ""prosecutors"", ""politicians"", ""welcome"", ""america""], [""many"", ""police""], [""fueled"", ""public"", ""fear"", ""agencies"", ""bleeding"", ""us"", ""dry"", ""emptying"", ""wallets""], [""spend"", ""trillions"", ""healthcare"", ""probably"", ""greatest"", ""health"", ""issue"", ""handed"", ""police"", ""solve""], [""talk"", ""dark"", ""ages""], [""clean"", ""drug"", ""issue"", ""shrink"", ""police""]]","[[""NN"", ""NN"", ""NN"", ""VBD"", ""NN""], [""VB"", ""NNS"", ""NNS"", ""NN"", ""VBG"", ""NNS"", ""NNS"", ""JJ"", ""NNP""], [""JJ"", ""NNS""], [""VBN"", ""JJ"", ""NN"", ""NNS"", ""VBG"", ""PRP"", ""JJ"", ""VBG"", ""NNS""], [""VBP"", ""NNS"", ""NN"", ""RB"", ""JJS"", ""NN"", ""NN"", ""VBN"", ""NN"", ""VB""], [""VB"", ""JJ"", ""NNS""], [""JJ"", ""NN"", ""NN"", ""VB"", ""NN""]]",drug war racism started war. throw media movies self serving prosecutors politicians welcome america. many police. fueled public fear agencies bleeding us dry emptying wallets. spend trillions healthcare probably greatest health issue handed police solve. talk dark ages. clean drug issue shrink police,"[""police""]",police,1,1;;;;

Steve Bell,"The problem is how nasty, vulgar, and hate filled many of those unmoderated comments can be. Until the web provided unfiltered commentary, an editor always moderated publication. What we have in unmoderated commentary is often not the correcting of misstatements, or the expanding of the conversation, but commenters attacking other commenters, hurling insults, changing the subject to beat the commenter's drum. We get lots of Obama hate even when the subject isn't Obama. If we had a culture of common courtesy before this, it's been severely jeopardized by coarse talk in comment sections. Steve Bell,"The problem is how nasty, vulgar, and hate filled many of those unmoderated comments can be. Until the web provided unfiltered commentary, an editor always moderated publication. What we have in unmoderated commentary is often not the correcting of misstatements, or the expanding of the conversation, but commenters attacking other commenters, hurling insults, changing the subject to beat the commenter's drum. We get lots of Obama hate even when the subject isn't Obama. If we had a culture of common courtesy before this, it's been severely jeopardized by coarse talk in comment sections. We even see that coarseness celebrated now as a good thing.",comment sections,A2836-P,unmoderated comments,0,2,16495,18244954,"[[""problem"", ""nasty"", ""vulgar"", ""hate"", ""filled"", ""many"", ""unmoderated"", ""comments""], [""web"", ""provided"", ""unfiltered"", ""commentary"", ""editor"", ""always"", ""moderated"", ""publication""], [""unmoderated"", ""commentary"", ""often"", ""correcting"", ""misstatements"", ""expanding"", ""conversation"", ""commenters"", ""attacking"", ""commenters"", ""hurling"", ""insults"", ""changing"", ""subject"", ""beat"", ""commenter"", ""'s"", ""drum""], [""get"", ""lots"", ""obama"", ""hate"", ""even"", ""subject"", ""n't"", ""obama""], [""culture"", ""common"", ""courtesy"", ""'s"", ""severely"", ""jeopardized"", ""coarse"", ""talk"", ""comment"", ""sections""], [""even"", ""see"", ""coarseness"", ""celebrated"", ""good"", ""thing""]]","[[""NN"", ""JJ"", ""JJ"", ""VBP"", ""VBN"", ""JJ"", ""JJ"", ""NNS""], [""NN"", ""VBN"", ""JJ"", ""NN"", ""NN"", ""RB"", ""VBD"", ""NN""], [""JJ"", ""NN"", ""RB"", ""NN"", ""NNS"", ""NN"", ""NN"", ""NNS"", ""VBG"", ""NNS"", ""VBG"", ""NNS"", ""VBG"", ""NN"", ""VB"", ""NN"", ""POS"", ""NN""], [""VBP"", ""NNS"", ""NNP"", ""VBP"", ""RB"", ""NN"", ""RB"", ""NNP""], [""NN"", ""JJ"", ""NN"", ""VBZ"", ""RB"", ""VBN"", ""JJ"", ""NN"", ""NN"", ""NNS""], [""RB"", ""VBP"", ""NN"", ""VBD"", ""JJ"", ""NN""]]",problem nasty vulgar hate filled many unmoderated comments. web provided unfiltered commentary editor always moderated publication. unmoderated commentary often correcting misstatements expanding conversation commenters attacking commenters hurling insults changing subject beat commenter 's drum. get lots obama hate even subject n't obama. culture common courtesy 's severely jeopardized coarse talk comment sections. even see coarseness celebrated good thing,"[""unmoderated"", ""comment""]",unmoderated comment,0,1;;;;

A,"What is most disturbing about the troll menace is how a (presumably) small minority of posters can trash an entire thread of discussion. That could never happen in a public square (or Trump rally). So it seems that civic-minded people must not give in to the trolls. Otherwise, we are letting them restrict our freedom to share thoughtful opinion with others. A way must be found to vote out the trolls. For example, comments could be rated by readers as constructive or destructive. The more destructive the rating, the lower that comment falls to the bottom of the heap. Only the thoughtful, constructive posts, as rated by the community of readers, would remain at the top. It could be automated, thus, reducing the cost of hiring moderators. Do others see a flaw in this proposal?",comment sections,A2851-P,comment sections,0,1,945,18240859,"[[""disturbing"", ""troll"", ""menace"", ""presumably"", ""small"", ""minority"", ""posters"", p p s safler,"I am fully insured on my own and help finance Obamacare too. And I don't regret. Such obligations are imperative for a civilized society and a nation. These obligations pale in comparision with,( like all citizens do),the benefits, advantages and rights I enjoy at the same time. In fact, what I want is a far less complicated, straight-forward, far more liberal and universally applicable health care system that is at least comparable to what are obtaining presently in France,UK and Scandinavia.I don't mind the personal costs,no one should, I believe.It is the basic minimum that any nation should render to its citizens.And it could prove to be quite cheaper than whatever provided by any insurance company and far more efficient, if wisely administered. Anyway, I personally believe, ofcourse buttressed by my own calculations and ratified by my intellectual friends, that the rich are indeed the free loaders in any society, extracting far higher benefits from it than what they themselves contribute.But they make the maximum noise and grossly distort the reality for denying the middle class and the poor what they richly deserve-- through Tina Kubicka,"As a former teacher and long-time first grade volunteer in a low income school district, I regularly use the CLEVNET system to get books for our class that compliment our curriculum or that are about subjects in which the kids express interest. We develop a reading list of the books shared each year, and let kids know they have access to them all through our local library. For communities in which books are an unaffordable luxury, libraries level the playing field, giving access to unlimited literary riches to all. In our community, they also provide much needed parenting help through story times and reading activities for caregivers and young children every week. Many families without computers at home get access to the internet at the library for homework help, employment and tax information. While libraries may be redundant for more affluent families, they provide a window into a different present and future for those of lesser means.",libraries,A1579-P,libraries,1,1,1966,7957857,"[[""former"", ""teacher"", ""long"", ""time"", ""first"", ""grade"", ""volunteer"", ""low"", ""income"", ""school"", ""district"", ""regularly"", p,"The penmanship my children (now ages 10 and 13) have been taught in school will suffice. It is neat, efficient and legible. There is no need to require them to become proficient in a second, archaic form of handwriting. Requiring children to learn how to read and write cursive at this point in history seems about as useful as requiring them to learn Fraktur or calligraphy. Once elementary school children have mastered standard penmanship a more effective use of school time would be to provide instruction and practice in using a keyboard.",students,A3691-P,students,1,1,12778,8891745,"[[""penmanship"", ""children"", ""ages"", ""10"", ""13"", ""taught"", ""school"", ""suffice""], [""neat"", ""efficient"", ""legible""], [""need"", ""require"", ""become"", ""proficient"", ""second"", ""archaic"", ""form"", ""handwriting""], [""requiring"", ""children"", ""learn"", ""read"", ""write"", ""cursive"", ""point"", ""history"", ""seems"", ""useful"", ""requiring"", ""learn"", ""fraktur"", ""calligraphy""], [""elementary"", ""school"", ""children"", ""mastered"", ""standard"", ""penmanship"", ""effective"", ""use"", ""school"", ""time"", ""would"", ""provide"", ""instruction"", ""practice"", ""using"", ""keyboard""]]","[[""NN"", ""NNS"", ""VBZ"", ""CD"", ""CD"", ""VBN"", ""NN"", ""VB""], [""JJ"", ""JJ"", ""JJ""], [""NN"", ""VB"", ""VB"", ""JJ"", ""JJ"", ""JJ"", ""NN"", ""NN""], [""VBG"", ""NNS"", ""VB"", ""VB"", ""VB"", ""NN"", ""NN"", ""NN"", ""VBZ"", ""JJ"", ""VBG"", ""VB"", ""NNP"", ""NN""], [""JJ"", ""NN"", ""NNS"", ""VBN"", ""JJ"", ""NN"", ""JJ"", ""NN"", ""NN"", ""NN"", ""MD"", ""VB"", ""NN"", ""NN"", ""VBG"", ""NN""]]",penmanship children ages 10 13 taught school suffice. neat efficient legible. need require become proficient second archaic form handwriting. requiring children learn read write cursive point history seems useful requiring learn fraktur calligraphy. elementary school children mastered standard penmanship effective use school time would provide instruction practice using keyboard,"[""student""]",student,1,0;;;;

Sarah,"The top two reasons cats are turned into shelters are house soiling and aggression (biting). It is a well-known fact that declawed cats are deprived of their main form of defense (claws), and resort to biting. Additionally, it is painful for many declawed cats to dig in a litter box. Hence, house soiling. Shelters I have volunteered at have quite a few declawed cats come in due to these reasons, declawing being the source of these issues. Pet owners who want to declaw a cat should not have a cat--period. If you want to protect your furniture, do not own a cat. Cats naturally scratch. If dog owners don't want their animal to jump on their couches or beds, do they remove a dog's leg? If dog owners don't want a dog to bark, is debarking humane? It's the same thing as declawing a cat. Sarah,"The top two reasons cats are turned into shelters are house soiling and aggression (biting). It is a well-known fact that declawed cats are deprived of their main form of defense (claws), and resort to biting. Additionally, it is painful for many declawed cats to dig in a litter box. Hence, house soiling. Shelters I have volunteered at have quite a few declawed cats come in due to these reasons, declawing being the source of these issues. Pet owners who want to declaw a cat should not have a cat--period. If you want to protect your furniture, do not own a cat. Cats naturally scratch. If dog owners don't want their animal to jump on their couches or beds, do they remove a dog's leg? If dog owners don't want a dog to bark, is debarking humane? It's the same thing as declawing a cat. Just don't have one.",your cat,A871-P,declawing cats,0,2,15888,17012077,"[[""top"", ""two"", ""reasons"", ""cats"", ""turned"", ""shelters"", ""house"", ""soiling"", ""aggression"", ""biting""], Harry,"I find the comment section indispensable especially when reading an opinion piece in culling the purported facts with other website links, pointing out sloppy reasoning or offering an alternative opinion. John,"Mr. Perry makes a very reasonable argument, but I think there are very few Spud Webbs out there anymore. Most of the pros are probably a good 6 inches taller than they were even 20 or 25 years ago, let alone 100, so you would think raising the rim is a reasonable alternative. Kathryn Cox,"I look forward to reading comments in the NYT's and for the most part, I'm on board and learn from many of the commenters both regular and occasional. On occasion, I've attempted to read comments on other news sites and find that many of them contain back and forth banter for lack of a better word between two people with little input from others. This gets old rather quickly. I choose to read the intelligent and well thought out comments both from the left and right. I do lean more to those comments that lean more to the left. I subscribe to the paper but do check out the editorials and opinion pieces on line just to see what some of my favorite commenters have to say.",comment sections,A2754-P,comment sections,1,1,15006,18247033,"[[""look"", ""forward"", ""reading"", ""comments"", ""nyt"", ""'s"", ""part"", ""'m"", ""board"", ""learn"", ""many"", ""commenters"", ""regular"", ""occasional""], [""occasion"", ""'ve"", ""attempted"", ""read"", ""comments"", ""news"", ""sites"", ""find"", ""many"", ""contain"", ""back"", ""forth"", ""banter"", ""lack"", ""better"", ""word"", ""two"", ""people"", ""little"", ""input"", ""others""], [""gets"", ""old"", ""rather"", ""quickly""], [""choose"", ""read"", ""intelligent"", ""well"", ""thought"", ""comments"", ""left"", ""right""], [""lean"", ""comments"", ""lean"", ""left""], [""subscribe"", ""paper"", ""check"", ""editorials"", ""opinion"", ""pieces"", ""line"", ""see"", ""favorite"", ""commenters"", ""say""]]","[[""VBP"", ""RB"", ""VBG"", ""NNS"", ""NNP"", ""POS"", ""NN"", ""VBP"", ""NN"", ""VB"", ""JJ"", ""NNS"", ""JJ"", ""JJ""], [""NN"", ""VB"", ""VBN"", ""VB"", ""NNS"", ""NN"", ""NNS"", ""VBP"", ""JJ"", ""VBP"", ""RB"", ""RB"", ""NN"", ""NN"", ""JJR"", ""NN"", ""CD"", ""NNS"", ""JJ"", ""NN"", ""NNS""], [""VBZ"", ""JJ"", ""RB"", ""RB""], [""VBP"", ""VB"", ""JJ"", ""RB"", ""VBN"", ""NNS"", ""NN"", ""NN""], [""VB"", ""NNS"", ""VBP"", ""NN""], [""VBP"", ""NN"", ""VB"", ""NNS"", ""NN"", ""NNS"", ""NN"", ""VB"", ""JJ"", ""NNS"", ""VB""]]",look forward reading comments nyt 's part 'm board learn many commenters regular occasional. occasion 've attempted read comments news sites find many contain back forth banter lack better word two people little input others. gets old rather quickly. choose read intelligent well thought comments left right. lean comments lean left. subscribe paper check editorials opinion pieces line see favorite commenters say,"[""comment"", ""section""]",comment section,1,0;;;;

Peter B,"As a restaurant owner & operator the idea of selling reservations is problematic, made only worse by the idea that a third party might me making money from the popularity that a restaurant has generated. But as JJ points out, the public has no problem paying less for dining during less desirable hours, why should they be opposed to paying more for prime time? We regularly pay more for better seats at events, but if the price of my menu items increased between 7 & 9 on my busiest nights, or if I charged a premium for my best tables, I would be vilified. Charging a premium for the most desired reservation times seems to be the best free-market solution, but the premium should go to the restaurant,",a way for people to get into popular Peter B,"As a restaurant owner & operator the idea of selling reservations is problematic, made only worse by the idea that a third party might me making money from the popularity that a restaurant has generated. But as JJ points out, the public has no problem paying less for dining during less desirable hours, why should they be opposed to paying more for prime time? We regularly pay more for better seats at events, but if the price of my menu items increased between 7 & 9 on my busiest nights, or if I charged a premium for my best tables, I would be vilified. Charging a premium for the most desired reservation times seems to be the best free-market solution, but the premium should go to the restaurant,",the new apps,A2941-P,surge Steve,"""Congress should stop Obamacare before it starts, and focus on common-sense solutions that can reduce health care costs for all Americans."" Except that we never seem to see what these ""common-sense solutions"" might actually consist of. As a liberal who opposed Obamacare because it's not what we really need--which is socialized medicine, by whatever name you might want to call it--I'm certainly all ears for other solutions. But I never see anything viable coming from the modern Right, just some mealy-mouthed phrases that camouflage their intent to do nothing at all. And why should we? The heart of Obamacare, the individual mandate, originated at the Heritage Foundation. Obama enacted a tweaked version of the GOP plan for healthcare reform and no one hates it more than the GOP.",obamacare,A1462-P,obamacare,0,1,16697,10095998,"[[""congress"", ""stop"", ""obamacare"", rob colter,"In my experience as a college department chair, it was frequently the professors with the fewest assignments and highest average student grades who received the most glowing reviews. Professors who set more challenging but reasonable standards were on the avoid list. Given the generally subjective nature of online reviews one should not be surprised at this. But neither should one claim that such reviews offer a fair evaluation of the product.",rate professors,A4748-P,rate professors,0,1,3534,16967039,"[[""experience"", ""college"", ""department"", ""chair"", ""frequently"", ""professors"", ""fewest"", ""assignments"", ""highest"", ""average"", ""student"", ""grades"", ""received"", ""glowing"", ""reviews""], [""professors"", ""set"", ""challenging"", ""reasonable"", ""standards"", ""avoid"", ""list""], [""given"", ""generally"", ""subjective"", ""nature"", ""online"", ""reviews"", ""one"", ""surprised""], [""neither"", ""one"", ""claim"", ""reviews"", ""offer"", ""fair"", ""evaluation"", ""product""]]","[[""NN"", ""NN"", ""NN"", ""NN"", ""RB"", ""NNS"", ""JJS"", ""NNS"", ""JJS"", ""JJ"", ""NN"", ""NNS"", ""VBD"", ""JJ"", ""NNS""], [""NNS"", ""VBD"", ""JJ"", ""JJ"", ""NNS"", ""NN"", ""NN""], [""VBN"", ""RB"", ""JJ"", ""NN"", ""JJ"", ""NNS"", ""PRP"", ""JJ""], [""DT"", ""CD"", ""VB"", ""NNS"", ""VBP"", ""JJ"", ""NN"", ""NN""]]",experience college department chair frequently professors fewest assignments highest average student grades received glowing reviews. professors set challenging reasonable standards avoid list. given generally subjective nature online reviews one surprised. neither one claim reviews offer fair evaluation product,"[""rate"", ""professor""]",rate professor,0,0;;;;

JTrent,"Well, I looked up the statistics on policemen being shot. Turns out that were about 100 in the year 2013. That's among more than 1.1 million full time and 40,000 part time officers. I'm not so sure this trainer should be showing trainees so many videos of shootings. Traffic and other accidents might be just as lethal. Over preparation and paranoia cannot be helpful.",police,A4471-P,police,0,1,3157,14663042,"[[""well"", ""looked"", ""statistics"", ""policemen"", ""shot""], [""turns"", ""100"", ""year"", ""2013""], [""'s"", ""among"", ""1.1"", ""million"", ""full"", ""time"", ""40,000"", ""part"", ""time"", ""officers""], [""'m"", ""sure"", ""trainer"", ""showing"", ""trainees"", ""many"", ""videos"", ""shootings""], [""traffic"", ""accidents"", ""might"", ""lethal""], [""preparation"", ""paranoia"", ""helpful""]]","[[""UH"", ""VBD"", ""NNS"", ""NNS"", ""VBN""], [""VBZ"", ""CD"", ""NN"", ""CD""], [""VBZ"", ""IN"", ""CD"", ""CD"", ""JJ"", ""NN"", ""CD"", ""NN"", ""NN"", ""NNS""], [""VBP"", ""JJ"", ""NN"", ""VBG"", ""NNS"", ""JJ"", ""NNS"", ""NNS""], [""NN"", ""NNS"", ""MD"", ""JJ""], [""NN"", ""NN"", ""JJ""]]","well looked statistics policemen shot. turns 100 year 2013. mary,"This is definitely a fluff 'issue', but very entertaining. My hypothesis is that people partner best with someone who's relatively compatible on the maintenance spectrum. As a low-maintenance type of gal, the sort who can get ready for an evening out in under 20 minutes (and that includes the shower), I would not be able to tolerate a guy who had 'manny-pedis' and facials. The very idea would make me cringe. Many years ago in my 20s I went on a few dates with a guy who had more hair grooming products than I did;" it just didn't work out. I've been married 15 years now to a handsome guy who is clean but doesn't primp or spend time worrying about grey hair or wrinkles. The only scent he gives off is from his deodorant and soap
post: and that's fine by me.""
column150: definitely fluff issue entertaining. hypothesis people partner best someone 's relatively compatible maintenance spectrum. low maintenance type gal sort get ready evening 20 minutes includes shower would able tolerate guy manny pedis facials. idea would make cringe. many years ago 20s went dates guy hair grooming products n't work. 've married 15 years handsome guy clean n't primp spend time worrying grey hair wrinkles. scent gives deodorant soap 's fine

author: K.M.,Oversalting in the kitchen is the best way to kill a dish. Some chefs have a salty pallate. Tastes good to them but tastes like a salt bomb to others. There are plenty of chefs that fall into this category. Those chefs will continue cooking even after they see dishes getting sent back to the kitchen. If there's a salt shaker at the table they know they can add less salt than they would prefer and let the diner adjust the salt at the table. May the salt shaker remain.,salt,A1775-P,salt,1,1,10875,9948546,"[[""oversalting"", ""kitchen"", ""best"", ""way"", ""kill"", ""dish""], [""chefs"", ""salty"", ""pallate""], [""tastes"", ""good"", ""tastes"", ""like"", ""salt"", ""bomb"", ""others""], [""plenty"", ""chefs"", ""fall"", ""category""], [""chefs"", ""continue"", ""cooking"", ""even"", ""see"", ""dishes"", ""getting"", ""sent"", ""back"", ""kitchen""], [""'s"", ""salt"", ""shaker"", ""table"", ""know"", ""add"", ""less"", ""salt"", ""would"", ""prefer"", ""let"", ""diner"", ""adjust"", ""salt"", ""table""], [""may"", ""salt"", ""shaker"", ""remain""]]","[[""VBG"", ""NN"", ""JJS"", ""NN"", ""VB"", ""NN""], [""NNS"", ""JJ"", ""NN""], [""NNS"", ""JJ"", ""VBZ"", ""IN"", ""NN"", ""NN"", ""NNS""], [""NN"", ""NNS"", ""VBP"", ""NN""], [""NNS"", ""VB"", ""VBG"", ""RB"", ""VBP"", ""NNS"", ""VBG"", ""VBN"", ""RB"", ""NN""], [""VBZ"", ""NN"", ""NN"", ""NN"", ""VBP"", ""VB"", ""JJR"", ""NN"", ""MD"", ""VB"", ""VB"", ""NN"", ""VB"", ""NN"", ""NN""], [""MD"", ""NN"", ""NN"", ""VBP""]]",oversalting kitchen best way kill dish. chefs salty pallate. tastes good tastes like salt bomb others. plenty chefs fall category. chefs continue cooking even see dishes getting sent back kitchen. K.M.,Oversalting in the kitchen is the best way to kill a dish. Some chefs have a salty pallate. Tastes good to them but tastes like a salt bomb to others. There are plenty of chefs that fall into this category. Those chefs will continue cooking even after they see dishes getting sent back to the kitchen. If there's a salt shaker at the table they know they can add less salt than they would prefer and let the diner adjust the salt at the table. Rev. Karen Tudor,"In our community, the most elegant, welcoming and practical buildings are our libraries. In the 9 years I have lived here, two libraries have been built and one redesigned and refurbished. Like the comments about the need for internet access among the poor, libraries ARE so much more. They have become a cultural, community hub for education, community activism, art, music, video and social interaction. One library has attracted the local gardening society to create and maintain a butterfly garden with many native plants that are marked for people to learn about them. Another group has offered to create a meandering walking path around the expanse of the building for reflection and a chance to walk in beauty outdoors. In many ways, I see our libraries becoming a sort of secular ministry -- feeding the souls as well as the minds of people. They are far from obsolete -- they are becoming more relevant and essential than ever before!",libraries,A1615-P,libraries,1,1,16941,7955845,"[[""community"", ""elegant"", ""welcoming"", jms175,"A national birth registry would be unnecessary if birthright citizenship were restricted to those in the country legally. Patricia,I don't think the drug reform or criminal justice reform movements would be where they are right now if not for the power of online comments. The media status quo have in the past supported the Drug War without question and played respectability politics to keep drug reform arguments out of the public eye. That's one of the things that got us into mass incarceration in the first place. A big reason why we are moving out of that period now is because various people outside the media elite who have their facts together on drug and criminal justice reform were able to use comments sections to communicate arguments about race and drug enforcement and criminal justice policy that the media status quo wasn't ready to play in prime time. This wound up educating the media status quo and now the way the media cover drug policy has changed completely. This is a victory for democracy and for online comments.,comment sections,A2800-P,comment sections,1,1,16080,18249097,"[[""n't"", ""think"", ""drug"", ""reform"", ""criminal"", ""justice"", John Smith,"A SINGLE PAYOR Plan such as they have in Germany, England and France, holds the potential for being a functional alternative for the US. But we are stuck with a crazy quilt of 50 different states each vying for its own version of Obamacare, anti-Obamacare or whatever else title they wish to dream up. You don't hear great upheavals from those receiving Medicare. It works. It's imperfect. Anything human is imperfect. That's evidence that a single payor program is already working here and can be expanded upon.",obamacare,A4906-P,obamacare,1,1,7914,19606929,"[[""single"", ""payor"", ""plan"", ""germany"", ""england"", ""france"", ""holds"", ""potential"", ""functional"", ""alternative"", ""us""], [""stuck"", ""crazy"", ""quilt"", ""50"", ""different"", ""states"", ""vying"", ""version"", ""obamacare"", ""anti"", ""obamacare"", ""whatever"", ""else"", ""title"", ""wish"", ""dream""], [""n't"", ""hear"", ""great"", ""upheavals"", ""receiving"", ""medicare""], [""works""], [""'s"", ""imperfect""], [""anything"", ""human"", ""imperfect""], [""'s"", ""evidence"", ""single"", ""payor"", ""program"", ""already"", ""working"", ""expanded"", ""upon""]]","[[""JJ"", ""NNP"", ""NN"", ""NNP"", ""NNP"", ""NNP"", ""VBZ"", ""NN"", ""JJ"", ""NN"", ""NNP""], [""VBN"", ""JJ"", ""NN"", ""CD"", ""JJ"", ""NNS"", ""VBG"", ""NN"", ""NNP"", ""RB"", ""NN"", ""WDT"", ""JJ"", ""NN"", ""VBP"", ""VB""], [""RB"", ""VB"", ""JJ"", ""NNS"", ""VBG"", ""NNP""], [""VBZ""], [""VBZ"", ""JJ""], [""NN"", ""JJ"", ""JJ""], [""VBZ"", ""NN"", ""JJ"", ""NN"", ""NN"", ""RB"", ""VBG"", ""VBN"", ""IN""]]",single payor plan germany england france holds potential functional alternative us. stuck crazy quilt 50 different states vying version obamacare anti obamacare whatever else title wish dream. n't hear great upheavals receiving medicare. works. Nicholas,"This is from the study that this writer Christie Wilcox cited about Organic farms being less ""efficient."" ""We found crop yields to be 20% lower in the organic systems, although input of fertilizer and energy was reduced by 34 to 53% and pesticide input by 97%. Enhanced soil fertility and higher biodiversity found in organic plots may render these systems less dependent on external inputs."" With the reduction in energy and pesticides they seem pretty efficient to me. All organic practices are not equal. Organic systems that ""stack"" crops like growing mushrooms beneath orchards or ducks and fish being raised along side rice patties are way more ""efficient"" than conventional. Science does prove organics are healthier and safer. The irony of that recent Stanford paper is that it showed there are less antibiotic resistant bacteria on organic meat and less pesticide residue on produce. Produce grown in biologically active soil, which is achieved using organic soil building methods, does have more testable ultra-trace minerals. Scientists are only now understanding how important these minerals are to human health. The holes in Christie Wilcox's argument are far and wide.",organic food,A928-P,organic food,1,1,2097,7091605,"[[""study"", ""writer"", ""christie"", ""wilcox"", ""cited"", ""organic"", ""farms"", Nicholas,"This is from the study that this writer Christie Wilcox cited about Organic farms being less ""efficient."" ""We found crop yields to be 20% lower in the organic systems, although input of fertilizer and energy was reduced by 34 to 53% and pesticide input by 97%. Enhanced soil fertility and higher biodiversity found in organic plots may render these systems less dependent on external inputs."" With the reduction in energy and pesticides they seem pretty efficient to me. All organic practices are not equal. Organic systems that ""stack"" crops like growing mushrooms beneath orchards or ducks and fish being raised along side rice patties are way more ""efficient"" than conventional. Science does prove organics are healthier and safer. The irony of that recent Stanford paper is that it showed there are less antibiotic resistant bacteria on organic meat and less pesticide residue on produce. Produce grown in biologically active soil, which is achieved using organic soil building methods, does have more testable ultra-trace minerals. Scientists are only now understanding how important these minerals are to human health. The holes in Christie Wilcox's argument are far and wide.",the expense,A929-P,inefficiency of organic farms,1,2,2111,7091605,"[[""study"", ""writer"", ""christie"", ""wilcox"", ""cited"", ""organic"", Hydraulic Engineer,"I am a frequent comment contributor to this NY Times Comments section, and an even more frequent reader of comments by others here. Please, keep this comment service! I usually read an article that interests me, then immediately read the NY Times selection of representative comments with great relish, because I know that there is a community of bright, well meaning, and responsible comment writers who will provide perspectives missing from the original article. Such good writers many of the commenters are! I regularly have my opinion affected by the comments in the NY Times. That said, the comment sections from virtually all other publications I have encountered are unfortunately dominated by people venting often foolish, badly written, negative comments. Such publications should either upgrade their comment section by adding adequate pre-publishing review, or I would sadly agree that those comment sections should be dropped.",comment RB,"I personally think that any organization allowed to provide Press Cards to its employees should be required by the law to have a public section comment on its website. Think about it, people are being put in jail to protect the right of journalists. The least they can do is defending the freedom of speech of others, journalists need to be held accountable on that, a right without a duty is an oligarchic priviledge. They should be required to provide and sustain a space for open debate for any information they provide. Comments sections have fails because media failed them by treating them as after thoughts, and under investing in them. What's missing is a whole ecosystem of accountability as far as journalism and freedom of speech are concerned.",comment sections,A2819-P,comment sections,1,1,12525,18247080,"[[""personally"", ""think"", ""organization"", ""allowed"", ""provide"", ""press"", ""cards"", ""employees"", ""required"", ""law"", ""public"", ""section"", ""comment"", ""website""], [""think"", ""people"", ""put"", ""jail"", ""protect"", ""right"", ""journalists""], [""least"", ""defending"", ""freedom"", ""speech"", ""others"", ""journalists"", ""need"", ""held"", ""accountable"", ""right"", ""without"", ""duty"", ""oligarchic"", ""priviledge""], [""required"", ""provide"", ""sustain"", ""space"", ""open"", ""debate"", ""information"", ""provide""], [""comments"", ""sections"", ""fails"", ""media"", ""failed"", ""treating"", ""thoughts"", ""investing""], [""'s"", ""missing"", ""whole"", ""ecosystem"", ""accountability"", ""far"", ""journalism"", ""freedom"", ""speech"", ""concerned""]]","[[""RB"", ""VBP"", ""NN"", ""VBN"", ""VB"", ""NNP"", ""NNP"", ""NNS"", ""VBN"", ""NN"", ""JJ"", ""NN"", ""NN"", ""NN""], [""VB"", ""NNS"", ""VBN"", ""NN"", ""VB"", ""NN"", ""NNS""], [""JJS"", ""VBG"", ""NN"", ""NN"", ""NNS"", ""NNS"", ""VBP"", ""VBN"", ""JJ"", ""NN"", ""IN"", ""NN"", ""JJ"", ""NN""], [""VBN"", ""VB"", ""VB"", ""NN"", ""JJ"", ""NN"", ""NN"", ""VBP""], [""NNS"", ""NNS"", ""VBZ"", ""NNS"", ""VBD"", ""VBG"", ""NNS"", ""VBG""], [""VBZ"", ""VBG"", ""JJ"", ""NN"", ""NN"", ""RB"", ""NN"", ""NN"", ""NN"", ""VBN""]]",personally think organization allowed provide press cards employees required law public section comment website. think people put jail protect right journalists. least defending freedom speech others journalists need held accountable right without duty oligarchic priviledge. required provide sustain space open debate information provide. comments sections fails media failed treating thoughts investing. mimio,"If libraries were used for information only, those who are there for the computers benefit from the librarians, who know where to find appropriate info. But there is so much more at the library--music and book cds, dvd films, magazines and much more. I have used and owned computers for many years, but I value the library as much as much as ever.",libraries,A1616-P,libraries,1,1,3056,7951790,"[[""libraries"", ""used"", ""information"", ""computers"", ""benefit"", ""librarians"", ""know"", ""find"", ""appropriate"", ""info""], [""much"", ""library"", ""--"", ""music"", ""book"", ""cds"", ""dvd"", ""films"", ""magazines"", ""much""], [""used"", ""owned"", ""computers"", ""many"", ""years"", ""value"", ""library"", ""much"", ""much"", ""ever""]]","[[""NNS"", ""VBN"", ""NN"", ""NNS"", ""VBP"", ""NNS"", ""VBP"", ""VB"", ""JJ"", ""NN""], [""RB"", ""NN"", "":"", ""NN"", ""NN"", ""NN"", ""NN"", ""NNS"", ""NNS"", ""RB""], [""VBN"", ""VBN"", ""NNS"", ""JJ"", ""NNS"", ""VBP"", ""NN"", ""RB"", ""JJ"", ""RB""]]",libraries used information computers benefit librarians know find appropriate info. much library -- music book cds dvd films magazines much. used owned computers many years value library much much ever,"[""library""]",library,1,1;;;;

pigenfrafyn,"Please do not take away the comment section in the NY Times! I will occasionally read comments on more conservative publications and marvel at the time people take to post hateful, nasty comments. But when I read the NY Times comment section, my faith in humanity is restored;" not only are the comments smart and well thought out
post: but because the Times has strict standards for publishing comments
ori_topic: there's certainly disagreement but never direct hatred and threats.""
label: comment sections
column99: please take away comment section ny times. occasionally read comments conservative publications marvel time people take post hateful nasty comments. read ny times comment section faith humanity restored comments smart well thought times strict standards publishing comments 's certainly disagreement never direct hatred threats

Travis,"This is just another job made obsolete by technology. All the arguments against it have been foisted in similar iterations of long forgotten jobs. DD,"Muddled thinking here. Muslims so often point out with alacrity that specific clothing (i.e., covering) is not defined in the Koran, yet here we are exposed to a Islamocentric defense of rules of female dress that are designed to restrict a woman's freedom. These public displays of religion, from yamakas to burkhas are offensive to those who hate religious tyranny, but, alas, must be tolerated. But don't tell me it's done for feminist reasons. There's nothing feminist at all about the three Abrahamic religions, which, together with their oppression of women, are used to justify so much violence today.",non-muslims,A2626-P,non-muslims,0,1,3322,17141178,"[[""muddled"", ""thinking""], [""muslims"", ""often"", ""point"", ""alacrity"", ""specific"", ""clothing"", ""i.e."", ""covering"", ""defined"", ""koran"", ""yet"", ""exposed"", ""islamocentric"", ""defense"", ""rules"", ""female"", ""dress"", ""designed"", ""restrict"", ""woman"", ""'s"", ""freedom""], [""public"", ""displays"", ""religion"", ""yamakas"", ""burkhas"", ""offensive"", ""hate"", ""religious"", ""tyranny"", ""alas"", ""must"", ""tolerated""], [""n't"", ""tell"", ""'s"", ""done"", ""feminist"", ""reasons""], [""'s"", ""nothing"", ""feminist"", ""three"", ""abrahamic"", ""religions"", ""together"", ""oppression"", ""women"", ""used"", ""justify"", ""much"", ""violence"", ""today""]]","[[""JJ"", ""NN""], [""NNS"", ""RB"", ""VBP"", ""NN"", ""JJ"", ""NN"", ""FW"", ""VBG"", ""VBN"", ""NNP"", ""CC"", ""VBN"", ""NNP"", ""NN"", ""NNS"", ""JJ"", ""NN"", ""VBN"", ""VB"", ""NN"", ""POS"", ""NN""], [""JJ"", ""NNS"", ""NN"", ""NNS"", ""NNS"", ""JJ"", ""VBP"", ""JJ"", ""NN"", ""UH"", ""MD"", ""VBN""], [""RB"", ""VB"", ""VBZ"", ""VBN"", ""JJ"", ""NNS""], [""VBZ"", ""NN"", ""JJ"", ""CD"", ""JJ"", ""NNS"", ""RB"", ""NN"", ""NNS"", ""VBN"", ""VB"", ""JJ"", ""NN"", ""NN""]]",muddled thinking. muslims often point alacrity specific clothing i.e. covering defined koran yet exposed islamocentric defense rules female dress designed restrict woman 's freedom. public displays religion yamakas burkhas offensive hate religious tyranny alas must tolerated. n't tell 's done feminist reasons. Lkf,"Goofy beyond belief. Religious beliefs are just that...beliefs. To whatever degree a religious practice is benign, it should be allowed. When the practice impinges upon public health or safety, it must be curtailed for the benefit of the entire society. Our tradition is not to concern ourselves with how people worship their god (or choose not to worship at all.) All are free to practice their religion as they see fit. Accordingly, we should also be able to choose to be free of religion when it impinges upon public health or well being. Nora,"Thank you! I could not agree more. I was an avid reader as a child and have grown to be an avid reader as an adult, and I believe that being a good reader is like training for being a good listener and ultimately a good citizen of the world. Learning to enter into the worlds and personas of book characters and understand their motivations and desires is good practice for listening to the people you encounter in life and coming to understand their perspective and ideas, even if you do not agree with them or do not initially have much in common with them. Certainly, it is important for parents and teachers to have good tools that help them approach complex political topics with children. But there is no reason why it should result in giving children didactic, joyless fiction.",children 's books,A4790-P,children 's books,0,1,2831,12252614,"[[""thank""], [""could"", ""agree""], Rick,"Bring back the drachma. If the Greek economy is slack, they can devalue the drachma to encourage foreign tourists and investment. They can also control their own destiny -- the basic concept of democracy which they created. Having Germany dictate how their government and economy should run doesn't make sense either for Germany or Athens. A Greece free of the Euro would be a happier and more prosperous Greece. mingsphinx,"""One of the main pillars of Syriza's economic program is the creation of 300,000 new jobs for the unemployed under a direct public employment scheme."" Anyone who thinks that expanding public employment in Greece is a good idea should migrate to Greece. There are already more public employees in Greece than just about anywhere else in the world and you propose to put more people on the public payroll? As it is, many government employees do not have any meaningful assignments and you want the Greek government to hire more people? What you are actually proposing is a massive expansion of welfare payments to the unemployed in Greece except that you claim to have given these people a job and so instead of social welfare you want the world to think of it as job creation. Here is a freebie for you: playing with words do not change economic realities. Greece cannot afford it and it is precisely such policies that created this mess in the first place.",greece 's,A817-P,greece 's,0,1,1264,13960651,"[[""one"", ""main"", ""pillars"", ""syriza"", mingsphinx,"""One of the main pillars of Syriza's economic program is the creation of 300,000 new jobs for the unemployed under a direct public employment scheme."" Anyone who thinks that expanding public employment in Greece is a good idea should migrate to Greece. There are already more public employees in Greece than just about anywhere else in the world and you propose to put more people on the public payroll? As it is, many government employees do not have any meaningful assignments and you want the Greek government to hire more people? What you are actually proposing is a massive expansion of welfare payments to the unemployed in Greece except that you claim to have given these people a job and so instead of social welfare you want the world to think of it as job creation. Here is a freebie for you: playing with words do not change economic realities. Greece cannot afford it and it is precisely such policies that created this mess in the first place.",greece 's,A817-P,free social welfare,0,2,1266,13960651,"[[""one"", ""main"", ""pillars"", GrammyofWandA,"I went back to school in my mid-40s and earned a PhD. As a middle-aged, overweight female in a highly competetive field, I found most internships automatically closed to me. I finally had to accept one that paid less than $200 per month--and I had to move 1000 miles from home (renting an apt.) to take it. I learned a lot, and returned home to a good career in my field (after a 2nd lowly-paid year elsewhere--but at least that covered rent). I do understand that the internship site had financial problems. But I am very much aware that I was able to take that internship ONLY because I was a married woman with a husband who worked, and money in the bank. That should not be the norm.",college students,A461-P,college students,1,1,7750,5445067,"[[""went"", ""back"", ""school"", ""mid-40s"", ""earned"", ""phd.""], [""middle"", ""aged"", ""overweight"", ""female"", ""highly"", ""competetive"", ""field"", ""found"", ""internships"", ""automatically"", ""closed""], [""finally"", ""accept"", ""one"", ""paid"", ""less"", ""200"", ""per"", ""month"", ""--"", ""move"", ""1000"", ""miles"", ""home"", ""renting"", ""apt""], [""take""], [""learned"", ""lot"", ""returned"", ""home"", ""good"", ""career"", ""field"", ""2nd"", ""lowly"", ""paid"", ""year"", ""elsewhere"", ""--"", ""least"", ""covered"", ""rent""], [""understand"", ""internship"", ""site"", ""financial"", ""problems""], [""much"", ""aware"", ""able"", ""take"", ""internship"", ""married"", ""woman"", ""husband"", ""worked"", ""money"", ""bank""], [""norm""]]","[[""VBD"", ""RB"", ""NN"", "":"", ""VBD"", ""NN""], [""NN"", ""JJ"", ""JJ"", ""NN"", ""RB"", ""JJ"", ""NN"", ""VBD"", ""NNS"", ""RB"", ""VBD""], [""RB"", ""VB"", ""CD"", ""VBD"", ""JJR"", ""CD"", ""IN"", ""NN"", "":"", ""VB"", ""CD"", ""NNS"", ""NN"", ""VBG"", ""NN""], [""VB""], [""VBD"", ""NN"", ""VBD"", ""RB"", ""JJ"", ""NN"", ""NN"", ""JJ"", ""RB"", ""VBN"", ""NN"", ""RB"", "":"", ""JJS"", ""VBD"", ""NN""], [""VB"", ""NN"", ""NN"", ""JJ"", ""NNS""], [""RB"", ""JJ"", ""JJ"", ""VB"", ""NN"", ""JJ"", ""NN"", ""NN"", ""VBD"", ""NN"", ""NN""], [""NN""]]",went back school mid-40s earned phd.. middle aged overweight female highly competetive field found internships automatically closed. finally accept one paid less 200 per month -- move 1000 miles home renting apt. take. learned lot returned home good career field 2nd lowly paid year elsewhere -- least covered rent. understand internship site financial problems. much aware able take internship married woman husband worked money bank. norm,"[""college"", ""student""]",college student,1,0;;;;

SD,"Abuse of birthright citizenship is not restricted only to undocumented immigrants. I see many H-1B holders (possibly with pending green card applications, but that's irrelevant) get married and have children in the US. Their children get US passports. This is a calculated move to take advantage of birthright citizenship. In some cases, they get married to people who aren't even in the US, bring the spouse over legally on H-4, and have children here.",birthright citizenship,A4188-P,birthright citizenship,0,1,12486,15881686,"[[""abuse"", ""birthright"", ""citizenship"", ""restricted"", ""undocumented"", ""immigrants""], [""see"", ""many"", ""h-1b"", ""holders"", ""possibly"", ""pending"", ""green"", ""card"", ""applications"", ""'s"", ""irrelevant"", ""get"", ""married"", ""children"", ""us""], [""children"", ""get"", ""us"", ""passports""], [""calculated"", ""move"", ""take"", ""advantage"", ""birthright"", ""citizenship""], [""cases"", ""get"", ""married"", ""people"", ""n't"", ""even"", ""us"", ""bring"", ""spouse"", ""legally"", ""h-4"", ""children""]]","[[""NN"", ""JJ"", ""NN"", ""VBN"", ""JJ"", ""NNS""], [""VBP"", ""JJ"", ""NNP"", ""NNS"", ""RB"", ""VBG"", ""JJ"", ""NN"", ""NNS"", ""VBZ"", ""JJ"", ""VBP"", ""VBN"", ""NNS"", ""NNP""], [""NNS"", ""VBP"", ""NNP"", ""NNS""], [""VBN"", ""NN"", ""VB"", ""NN"", ""JJ"", ""NN""], [""NNS"", ""VBP"", ""VBN"", ""NNS"", ""RB"", ""RB"", ""NNP"", ""VB"", ""NN"", ""RB"", ""NNP"", ""NNS""]]",abuse birthright citizenship restricted undocumented immigrants. see many h-1b holders possibly pending green card applications 's irrelevant get married children us. children get us passports. calculated move take advantage birthright citizenship. cases get married people n't even us bring spouse legally h-4 children,"[""birthright"", ""citizenship""]",birthright citizenship,1,1;;;;

ridgeguy,"I learn quite a lot from NYT comments, often and in particular from thoughtful comments by authors who think differently from me. I find them valuable. I think the Times' general level of commentary is good. This in part results from the Times' curating its comments, which filters the merely shrill or ad hominem screeds. I recognize this also introduces curatorial bias, but for me, the reduction in noise is welcome. I hope the Times continues to solicit reader commentary. I think its system is working well.",comment sections,A2818-P,comment sections,1,1,5258,18247132,"[[""learn"", ""quite"", ""lot"", ""nyt"", ""comments"", ""often"", ""particular"", ""thoughtful"", ""comments"", ""authors"", ""think"", ""differently""], [""find"", ""valuable""], [""think"", ""times"", ""general"", ""level"", ""commentary"", ""good""], [""part"", ""results"", ""times"", ""curating"", ""comments"", ""filters"", ""merely"", ""shrill"", ""ad"", ""hominem"", ""screeds""], [""recognize"", ""also"", ""introduces"", ""curatorial"", ""bias"", ""reduction"", ""noise"", ""welcome""], [""hope"", ""times"", ""continues"", ""solicit"", ""reader"", ""commentary""], [""think"", ""system"", ""working"", ""well""]]","[[""VBP"", ""PDT"", ""NN"", ""NNP"", ""NNS"", ""RB"", ""JJ"", ""JJ"", ""NNS"", ""NNS"", ""VBP"", ""RB""], [""VBP"", ""JJ""], [""VBP"", ""NNP"", ""JJ"", ""NN"", ""NN"", ""JJ""], [""NN"", ""NNS"", ""NNP"", ""VBG"", ""NNS"", ""VBZ"", ""RB"", ""JJ"", ""NN"", ""NN"", ""NNS""], [""VBP"", ""RB"", ""VBZ"", ""NN"", ""NN"", ""NN"", ""NN"", ""JJ""], [""VBP"", ""NNP"", ""VBZ"", ""VB"", ""NN"", ""NN""], [""VBP"", ""NN"", ""VBG"", ""RB""]]",learn quite lot nyt comments often particular thoughtful comments authors think differently. find valuable. think times general level commentary good. part results times curating comments filters merely shrill ad hominem screeds. recognize also introduces curatorial bias reduction noise welcome. hope times continues solicit reader commentary. think system working well,"[""comment"", ""section""]",comment section,1,0;;;;

Vanadias,"I urge Mr. Stankiewicz to do his due diligence--required by any good journalism major--and perform some research. Two major studies in the last decade have shown that student evaluations are wholly flawed ways of evaluating learning. In fact, there is some evidence for a negative correlation between student reviews and learning. In other words, the more students dislike a professor, the better those students do in similar classes down the road. Why? Because those professors challenge students to push past their comfort zones and rigid patterns of thinking. Oh, and if you're going to use that erroneous consumer metaphor, then at least get it right: professors are not the product--the student mind is the product, and preparing it for engagement in civil Jarvis,"While the government wants us to eat healthy, it is very true that organic foods are outrageously priced for the small amount of food we recieve. Yes, when going to McDonald's and getting 5 things off of the dollar menu you get more bang for your buck. However, that is one reason why America is in such bad shape literally and figuratively. Obviously organic products are healthier for you than genetically enhanced ones. The cows that produce the normal milk we drink are fed steroids to be able to produce more milk than naturally possible. Therefore, we are not consuming 100% pure milk. That can cut down the natural nutrients we would be recieving if everyone housed their own cow. So, this article couldn't be any more incorrect by saying that America is worse off consuming organic products. If everyone decided to trade out a bag of Lay's for some all natural vegetable chips, consumption sizes would be cut down and health could be improved.",organic food,A930-P,organic VHZ,"As an academic for more than 50 years, I say, especially around grading time, that every university should require two things: minimal competence in a (new) foreign language, and performance on a musical instrument. You can cheat or get around the requirements for all kinds of other academic subjects, but you either speak French in public, or you can't. You either play the Bach Invention, or you can't. Simple. You can't cram it, you can't cheat. Besides the obvious benefits of the learning processes in both of these activities, the study of each is a valuable exercise in integrity. Laurie C,"An incredible amount of time can be lost to technical issues with online classes (and with computers in classrooms). The discussion board doesn't open, links are broken, my browser won't open this or that page, the teacher can't find the file, we can't submit our work because the files are too big, students can't figure out how to make/open/save files, printers run out of ink, presentations disappear, and on and on and ON. One of these semesters I want to do research to see if using computers really does save time in the classroom. marriane,"Yes I'm wired and also have a Kindle and Netflix. Nevertheless I'm a heavy library user and can't imagine living in a community without these resources. My husband and I are now deciding where to retire -- just as we want a location with good medical facilities and an airport we also want a first class library system. We want to live in a community that respects literacy, reading and has good children's programs like story hour, etc.",libraries,A1592-P,libraries,1,1,12030,7951873,"[[""yes"", ""'m"", ""wired"", ""also"", ""kindle"", ""netflix""], [""nevertheless"", ""'m"", ""heavy"", ""library"", ""user"", ""ca"", ""n't"", ""imagine"", ""living"", ""community"", ""without"", ""resources""], [""husband"", ""deciding"", ""retire"", ""--"", ""want"", ""location"", ""good"", ""medical"", ""facilities"", ""airport"", ""also"", ""want"", ""first"", ""class"", ""library"", ""system""], [""want"", ""live"", ""community"", ""respects"", ""literacy"", ""reading"", ""good"", ""children"", ""'s"", ""programs"", ""like"", ""story"", ""hour"", ""etc""]]","[[""UH"", ""VBP"", ""JJ"", ""RB"", ""NNP"", ""NNP""], [""RB"", ""VBP"", ""JJ"", ""NN"", ""NN"", ""MD"", ""RB"", ""VB"", ""VBG"", ""NN"", ""IN"", ""NNS""], [""NN"", ""VBG"", ""VB"", "":"", ""VBP"", ""NN"", ""JJ"", ""JJ"", ""NNS"", ""NN"", ""RB"", ""VBP"", ""JJ"", ""NN"", ""NN"", ""NN""], [""VBP"", ""VB"", ""NN"", ""VBZ"", ""NN"", ""NN"", ""JJ"", ""NNS"", ""POS"", ""NNS"", ""IN"", ""NN"", ""NN"", ""FW""]]",yes 'm wired also kindle netflix. nevertheless 'm heavy library user ca n't imagine living community without resources. husband deciding retire -- want location good medical facilities airport also want first class library system. want live community respects literacy reading good children 's programs like story hour etc,"[""library""]",library,1,1;;;;

de Rigueur,"""Even beauty and mommy blogs and movie review websites are littered with the scourge of the earth, desperately seeking attention."" don,"The chef's vision, blah, blah, blah. Every so often at at otherwise decent restaurant, the chef of the moment under salts the food. Just plain and simple, they miss the mark. I understand, that happens, the food doesn't turn up on the table just as the chef intended when the dish was created. I am talking about a case in which the executive chef, were she tasting the food herself, would consider it under seasoned. In such a case when I am spending $38 on an entree, would the restaurant prefer I send it back and refuse to pay, or eat it and grumble about it on Yelp, or simply shake a little salt on it and be happy and tip well? It is the restaurant's choice. In addition, salt is not cinnamon. It is an absurd comparison. An under salted dish is unpalatable. A dish with less than optimal cinnamon is still fine.",salt,A1799-P,salt,1,1,4754,9952772,"[[""chef"", ""'s"", ""vision"", ""blah"", ""blah"", ""blah""], [""every"", ""often"", ""otherwise"", don,"The chef's vision, blah, blah, blah. Every so often at at otherwise decent restaurant, the chef of the moment under salts the food. Just plain and simple, they miss the mark. I understand, that happens, the food doesn't turn up on the table just as the chef intended when the dish was created. I am talking about a case in which the executive chef, were she tasting the food herself, would consider it under seasoned. In such a case when I am spending $38 on an entree, would the restaurant prefer I send it back and refuse to pay, or eat it and grumble about it on Yelp, or simply shake a little salt on it and be happy and tip well? It is the restaurant's choice. In addition, salt is not cinnamon. It is an absurd comparison. An under salted dish is unpalatable. A dish with less than optimal cinnamon is still fine.",a place at the table,A1800-P,an under salted dish is unpalatable,0,2,16123,9952772,"[[""chef"", ""'s"", ""vision"", ""blah"", ""blah"", Tuvw Xyz,"Readers' comments are a boon the advertising revenue of the paper: from an advertiser's point of view, a large number of comments indicates that the paper is read by many, therefore it is a fertile ground for placing ads in it. As to who writes anonymous comments: readers like Nightwood MI 5 minutes ago, who feel threatened; people like myself
post: whose pseudonym became their alter ego; people who want to share their views with others;" and people who want to surprise or even shock the Pharisee reader by unconventional ideas.""
column120: readers comments boon advertising revenue paper advertiser 's point view large number comments indicates paper read many therefore fertile ground placing ads. writes anonymous comments readers like nightwood mi 5 minutes ago feel threatened people like whose pseudonym became alter ego people want share views others people want surprise even shock pharisee reader unconventional ideas

author: S. Bait,"Because this is a right conferred on the baby who has not done anything wrong, this right should not be abolished.
