Iam,"Even the comments on the Washington Post are appalling. While one might think there would be some intelligent commentary accompanying news articles in that respected venue, a relatively small posse of regulars-on both sides of the political spectrum-seize every chance to hurl utterly unrelated partisan insults at one another. Sometimes I think the Post just republishes the same comment section day after day. And then I kick myself for wasting my time looking for signs of intelligent life. The Times, on the other hand, does a great job of moderating.",comment sections,A2798-P,comment sections,0,1,18191,18249225,"[[""even"", ""comments"", ""washington"", ""post"", ""appalling""], [""one"", ""might"", ""think"", ""would"", ""intelligent"", ""commentary"", ""accompanying"", ""news"", ""articles"", ""respected"", ""venue"", ""relatively"", ""small"", ""posse"", ""regulars"", ""sides"", ""political"", ""spectrum"", ""seize"", ""every"", ""chance"", ""hurl"", ""utterly"", ""unrelated"", ""partisan"", ""insults"", ""one"", ""another""], [""sometimes"", ""think"", ""post"", ""republishes"", ""comment"", ""section"", ""day"", ""day""], [""kick"", ""wasting"", ""time"", ""looking"", ""signs"", ""intelligent"", ""life""], [""times"", ""hand"", ""great"", ""job"", ""moderating""]]","[[""RB"", ""NNS"", ""NNP"", ""NNP"", ""JJ""], [""PRP"", ""MD"", ""VB"", ""MD"", ""JJ"", ""NN"", ""VBG"", ""NN"", ""NNS"", ""VBN"", ""NN"", ""RB"", ""JJ"", ""NN"", ""NNS"", ""NNS"", ""JJ"", ""NN"", ""VB"", ""DT"", ""NN"", ""VB"", ""RB"", ""JJ"", ""JJ"", ""NNS"", ""CD"", ""DT""], [""RB"", ""VBP"", ""NNP"", ""VBZ"", ""NN"", ""NN"", ""NN"", ""NN""], [""VBP"", ""VBG"", ""NN"", ""VBG"", ""NNS"", ""JJ"", ""NN""], [""NNP"", ""NN"", ""JJ"", ""NN"", ""VBG""]]",even comments washington post appalling. one might think would intelligent commentary accompanying news articles respected venue relatively small posse regulars sides political spectrum seize every chance hurl utterly unrelated partisan insults one another. sometimes think post republishes comment section day day. kick wasting time looking signs intelligent life. times hand great job moderating,"[""comment"", ""section""]",comment section,1,1;;;;

Stephen,"To echo Candide and others, professors who are on the market or do not have tenure often write their own reviews. MikeM,"Those already born here would, practically, have to be grandfathered if there were any changes. Reviewing the citizenship of people already born here would result in endless paperwork and heavy expenses, and would force us to make difficult moral decisions, some of which we would undoubtedly get wrong. I don't think that a constitutional amendment is actually necessary to clarify that the meaning of the Constitution is not something that it clearly was not intended to be, though. Defining the meaning of ""under the jurisdiction of the United States"" to exclude those who entered the country illegally or are here on short term travel visas should only require a law saying as much. The courts could strike it down, I suppose, but it's far from clear that they should, and their decision would have to explain some interesting contradictions between their position and contradictory aspects of past immigration laws. I think that the current problem is due to a lack of clarity from Congress, not due to actual demands of the Constitution.",birthright citizenship,A4182-P,birthright Erica,"I've been host to two declawed cats while trying to find them a home (They came to me this way, it would never be my choice to do this). During their stay, one of them managed to kill two birds quite efficiently without claws. (They wiggled their way through the air conditioner). I didn't see him do it to know his methods, but I know it was him. Just last week, my toothless cat killed a bird that got in the same way. He killed it with one blow of his paw. He didn't use his claws to bring it down; just one blow and it was dead. I will only leave this piece of information
post: for I could write a book on declawing cats and the pain and problems it causes. There are plenty of safe alternatives to declawing;" people need to research
ori_topic: and learn to live with animals instead of adapting them to fit our needs.""
label: your cat

author: lightbulb66,"I love national parks. Growing up in India, unspoiled green spaces were really foreign, and National Parks are America's best idea for generations to come. I visit Mt Ranier National Park several times as it is almost in my backyard. I am struck by the damage that visitors can inflict on the fragile wild flower meadows in their eagerness and zeal to enjoy the beauty. While better funding and visitor resources such as mass transportation could help, something we can all do is volunteer at a NP for a few days a year. This will go a long way in relieving the already stretched NP resources and the benefit to the volunteer citizen is priceless. Picking up trash, pulling weeks, cataloging wildflowers, roving the meadows helping visitors, etc. can help give back to our country's best idea and recharge our batteries all in one Leah,"In our 40 and some years of marriage, we have had 9 cats, and declawed all of them. Our cats are strictly indoor cats and most of them have lived 10 plus years (One even lived to 20!) without any of the behavioral problems described in this article. Our first cat destroyed our furniture and did not respond to all the behavior modification hints in these articles. If people are not allowed to declaw, I fear even more cats will be euthanized. Justice Holmes,Monopolies as monopolies are always dangerous which is why when one is permitted it must be under the tight control of the government and it must be by law committed to the betterment of the customer's interests and those of the public. Once a monopoly is permitted it is no longer a typical corporations competing with others. It is by definition the only place that a consumer can turn for that product or service thus its power to abuse that situation is massive and must be strictly controlled. It's price structure cannot be allowed to be government only by the corporations interests and the way it conducts its business must be a matter of public scrutiny. Google is no different....it has already shown its monopolistic tendencies by freezing out other content and preferring serve results thst are beneficial to it and its partners thus depriving users of intimations that may be beneficial to them. My preference would be not to allow any monopolies and to break up any that occur through mergers or other corproate transactions.,a harmful monopoly,A1928-P,a harmful Rahul,"Comments are necessary because Opinion pieces and publications are often promoting a narrow agenda that is masquerading as majority opinion and settled debate. Comments section balances out the opinion and offers an alternate view as well as evidence that contradicts the opinion piece. That is what a good debate is about. Comments should be moderated but with a light touch that allows legitimate discussion to get through. I would not read any article or publication that does not allow comments to get through. My opinion of an editorial or commentary immediately goes down and I ascribe less value to that article if it does not accept comments. Not accepting comments means that the author is afraid of debate and criticism and has this superior attitude, that I know more than you and therefore you have to accept my opinion as the the final word on this topic. No you are not, and no I don't have to!",comment sections,A2838-P,comment sections,1,1,3795,18243112,"[[""comments"", ""necessary"", ""opinion"", ""pieces"", ""publications"", ""often"", author: wcovenant,"The main reason educators argue against home schooling is because it works. It works so well, they have designed the system to work against the parents who chooses to become a primary educator to their own children. The legislators' should embrace the parent's decision and remove legislative road blocks that would hinder and disrespect a parent's unique role in their children's lives. I believe this is called progress in the right direction. One way to overcome this obstacle with sports would be a standardized test that would allow public and homeschooled students to participate in all extra curriculum activities without any bias or discriminatory practices. As it is now, home schooled students are being discriminated against.",home-schoolers,A1029-P,home-schoolers,1,1,7187,5477940,"[[""main"", ""reason"", ""educators"", ""argue"", ""home"", Dan Frazier,"The Internet would be a vastly different place if we could somehow do away with anonymity. But would it actually be a better place? In our very polarized world, many people are understandably reluctant to speak out on controversial issues, unless they can do so anonymously. If we want to know what people really think, we need to let them speak anonymously. So long as there has been written communication, people have had that ability, and maybe that right. Before that, people threw rocks under cover of darkness to get their point across. I understand the temptation to demand that people use their real identities, but it seems almost impossible to do in the real world. Even if you ask for a scan of my driver's license, you can't be sure it is really my license, or be sure that it has not been altered.",comment sections,A2764-P,comment ETC,"It may have made sense once upon a time but not anymore. I am liberal thinker and I don't mean to say that we need to deport people in mass or not have systems in place to care for newborns of any status who happen to be born here. But citizenship should be a priveledge that is applied for by families or legal representation in exceptional circumstances, and it should be earned thorugh a process by which it is clear the person (or family) is well invested in our culture and economy. I have two daughters born in Switzerland, neither of whom were offered Swiss citizenship at birth because the simple fact of their birth didn't make them Swiss. Under the current system it is simply too easy to take advantage of the current law and use automatic citizenship to take more than is earned. Again, I am not saying we shouldn't be a compassionate country, and how a new system is implemented would be a lengthy, difficult task, but it definitely should change.",birthright An Ordinary American,"Single payer is the obvious solution. We have a single payer system here in the Czech Republic. I can choose my doctor. I receive good care quickly. JS,"Don't jettison them altogether, moderate them the way the Times does. I love reading the comments in the Times, they are mostly well-written, and sometimes extremely well written, and I often learn more about the topic and various ways of thinking about it. Thanks, all you regular Times commentators! TeamVenture,"When I went to college a decade ago, the priced i paid for a single dorm room was less than a shared off-campus room. I did live in an older building with communal bathrooms, my room was tiny with a bed, desk, dresser and a small closet. Not only that, it gave my parents peace of mind that people in my building were enrolled students, opposite gender friends aren't supposed to stay overnight and an RA on every floor. At night if I needed to go somewhere on campus and felt unsafe, I could call the university for someone to walk with me. Obviously it you cannot afford to live outside of your home, that's that but for people to claim off campus housing is cheaper and everyone does it is plain TeamVenture,"When I went to college a decade ago, the priced i paid for a single dorm room was less than a shared off-campus room. I did live in an older building with communal bathrooms, my room was tiny with a bed, desk, dresser and a small closet. Not only that, it gave my parents peace of mind that people in my building were enrolled students, opposite gender friends aren't supposed to stay overnight and an RA on every floor. At night if I needed to go somewhere on campus and felt unsafe, I could call the university for someone to walk with me. Obviously it you cannot afford to live outside of your home, that's that but for people to claim off campus housing is cheaper and everyone does it is plain wrong.",campus,A2585-P,dorm Vanadias,"This reads like parody. Rate My Professors is an organized venue...with a chili pepper icon to evaluate professors' hotness, a techno-bureaucratic set of sliding scales to place people on a scale of 1-5, and rarely a serious or self-reflective comment about content, pace, or intellectual challenge. Ge real. It's a place to vent. And that venting can go either direction, too: students will sing the praise of one teacher, and assail another. Their are very few middle reviews. And why is that? Because the forum is self-selecting, and--through its rationalist design--it encourages yes or no evaluation. Is that what we want? Students who are encouraged to judge everything as either black or white?",rate professors,A4728-P,rate professors,0,1,14600,16967238,"[[""reads"", ""like"", ""parody""], [""rate"", ""professors"", ""organized"", ""venue"", ""..."", ""chili"", ""pepper"", ""icon"", ""evaluate"", ""professors"", ""hotness"", ""techno"", ""bureaucratic"", ""set"", ""sliding"", ""scales"", ""place"", ""people"", ""scale"", ""1"", ""5"", ""rarely"", ""serious"", ""self"", ""reflective"", ""comment"", ""content"", ""pace"", ""intellectual"", ""challenge""], [""ge"", ""real""], [""'s"", ""place"", ""vent""], [""venting"", ""go"", ""either"", ""direction"", ""students"", ""sing"", ""praise"", ""one"", ""teacher"", ""assail"", ""another""], [""middle"", ""reviews""], [""forum"", ""self"", ""selecting"", ""--"", ""rationalist"", ""design"", ""--"", ""encourages"", ""yes"", ""evaluation""], [""want""], [""students"", ""encouraged"", ""judge"", ""everything"", ""either"", ""black"", ""white""]]","[[""VBZ"", ""IN"", ""NN""], [""NNP"", ""NNPS"", ""JJ"", ""NN"", ""NFP"", ""JJ"", ""NN"", ""NN"", ""VB"", ""NNS"", ""NN"", ""NN"", ""JJ"", ""NN"", ""VBG"", ""NNS"", ""VB"", ""NNS"", ""NN"", ""CD"", ""CD"", ""RB"", ""JJ"", ""NN"", ""JJ"", ""NN"", ""NN"", ""NN"", ""JJ"", ""NN""], [""NNP"", ""JJ""], [""VBZ"", ""NN"", ""VB""], [""NN"", ""VB"", ""DT"", ""NN"", ""NNS"", ""VB"", ""NN"", ""CD"", ""NN"", ""VB"", ""DT""], [""JJ"", ""NNS""], [""NN"", ""NN"", ""VBG"", "":"", ""NN"", ""NN"", "":"", ""VBZ"", ""UH"", ""NN""], [""VBP""], [""NNS"", ""VBN"", ""VB"", ""NN"", ""DT"", ""JJ"", ""JJ""]]",reads like parody. rate professors organized venue ... chili pepper icon evaluate professors hotness techno bureaucratic set sliding scales place people scale 1 5 rarely serious self reflective comment content pace intellectual challenge. ge real. Mike,"The red meat and potato men are probably like my overweight, high blood pressure father, dead of a heart attack at 56. bkp5150,"According to the Mexican constitution, Article 30- one way for Mexican nationality is - Those born in a foreign country of Mexican parents; of a Mexican father and a foreign mother; or of a Mexican mother and an unknown father;" So if Trumps immigration plan begins with deportation for those from Mexico
post: it would in fact be deporting Mexican citizens...Mexico doesn't recognize them as American citizens. They are subject to the jurisdiction of Mexico.""

author: sb445,There are two issues: (a) Right now most gamblers tend to go to underground organization with sites hosted offshore. All the law would do is to move it to a regulatory oversight. (b) We can prevent suicidal gambling behavior by capping the amount of money a gambler can gamble away in a month by having a universal ID (so that he can't switch sites or games to gamble more). What we do not want is these vulnerable people to be exploited by criminals where US may not have any regulatory oversight.,internet gambling,A3294-P,internet gambling,0,1,236,2326100,"[[""two"", ""issues"", ""right"", ""gamblers"", ""tend"", ""go"", ""underground"", ""organization"", ""sites"", ""hosted"", ""offshore""], [""law"", ""would"", ""move"", ""regulatory"", ""oversight""], [""b"", ""prevent"", ""suicidal"", ""gambling"", ""behavior"", ""capping"", ""amount"", ""money"", ""gambler"", ""gamble"", ""away"", ""month"", ""universal"", ""id"", ""ca"", ""n't"", ""switch"", ""sites"", ""games"", ""gamble""], [""want"", ""vulnerable"", ""people"", ""exploited"", ""criminals"", ""us"", ""may"", ""regulatory"", ""oversight""]]","[[""CD"", ""NNS"", ""RB"", ""NNS"", ""VBP"", ""VB"", ""JJ"", ""NN"", ""NNS"", ""VBN"", ""RB""], [""NN"", ""MD"", ""VB"", ""JJ"", ""NN""], [""LS"", ""VB"", ""NN"", ""NN"", ""NN"", ""VBG"", ""NN"", ""NN"", ""NN"", ""VB"", ""RB"", ""NN"", ""JJ"", ""NNP"", ""MD"", ""RB"", ""VB"", ""NNS"", ""NNS"", ""VB""], [""VB"", ""JJ"", ""NNS"", ""VBN"", ""NNS"", ""NNP"", ""MD"", ""JJ"", ""NN""]]",two issues right gamblers tend go underground organization sites hosted offshore. law would move regulatory oversight. b prevent suicidal gambling behavior capping amount money gambler gamble away month universal id ca n't switch sites games gamble. want vulnerable people exploited criminals us may regulatory oversight,"[""internet"", ""gambling""]",internet gambling,1,0;;;;

Joy,"Publishing and newspapers are old industries. Publishing has fed too long from the labors of writers and readers while too seldom adding true value. Newspapers have been lean and efficient, they juat aren't capable of satisfying the demand curve of today's public. Telecommunications and transportation behaved similarly to publishing and they underwent dramatic restructuring. The music production industry is well on its way toward completing a shake up. It isn't pretty, but it is too late for publishing to control their future. Ten years ago they might have had more of a say in the direction the sector is going;" it is now pre-ordained.""

Jonathan Ariel,"Having been born ""Her Majesty's Loyal Subject (albeit Colonial-hence no longer one), I would like to see Charles become King before he reaches his mother' s age. Yes, I know William is much cooler. however whatever his shortcomings, Charles does not deserve the unprecedented humiliation of being passed over after waiting patiently and loyally for over 40 years. It's just not fair. I think Charles would be a reasonably good Monarch. His biggest problem is Camilla. I'm going to be brutally honest, and expect to get some flak as a result. Dianna was undoubtedly the Queen of Hearts, a star with a capital S, gorgeous, charismatic and blessed with incredible ability for empathy. However as Eliabeth has proven beyond doubt, one does not need to be a star to be a good monarch. Camilla is no Dianna, but she is, like it or not infinitely more suited to be Queen of the Realm then Dianna could ever hope to be.",queen elizabeth ii,A2893-P,queen elizabeth Al M,"As Truman stated so many years ago, ""It has become an operational and at times a policy-making arm of the Government. This has led to trouble and may have compounded our difficulties in several explosive areas."" Indeed, the CIA/NSA has become an all powerful, unaccountable, unconstitutional fourth wing of government in control of the Executive and running our foreign policy to the detriment of the world and of our basic rights as citizens. The CIA has always been above the law, uncontrollable and unaccountable. It is responsible for more crimes against humanity than any other organization or government, orchestrating civil wars, coups, establishing brutal dictatorships from Guatemala to Chile to Iran, training and overseeing death squads and torture around the globe. It is past time to abolish this monstrous institution along with its other faces;" NSA

author: meilaushi,"Right on! The watchword for any business, restaurants included, should generally be ""the customer is always right."" This is especially true with regard to tastes, and appreciation of flavors. People do not all experience the same food the same way and for an egotistic chef to imagine he has the right to determine how much salt should be put on something is ridiculous. The chef doesn't know best for everyone. So keep the salt and pepper shakers. They are the ubiquitous best flavor enhancers around--the very reason they are ubiquitous in any GOOD restaurant IMHO!",a place at the table,A1750-P,a place at the table,1,1,6421,9950813,"[[""right""], [""watchword"", ""business"", ""restaurants"", ""included"", ""generally"", ""customer"", ""always"", ""right""], [""especially"", ""true"", ""regard"", ""tastes"", ""appreciation"", ""flavors""], [""people"", ""experience"", ""food"", ""way"", ""egotistic"", ""chef"", ""imagine"", ""right"", ""determine"", ""much"", ""salt"", ""put"", ""something"", ""ridiculous""], [""chef"", ""n't"", ""know"", ""best"", ""everyone""], [""keep"", ""salt"", ""pepper"", ""shakers""], [""ubiquitous"", ""best"", ""flavor"", ""enhancers"", ""around"", ""--"", ""reason"", ""ubiquitous"", ""good"", ""restaurant"", ""imho""]]","[[""RB""], [""NN"", ""NN"", ""NNS"", ""VBN"", ""RB"", ""NN"", ""RB"", ""JJ""], [""RB"", ""JJ"", ""NN"", ""NNS"", ""NN"", ""NNS""], [""NNS"", ""VB"", ""NN"", ""NN"", ""JJ"", ""NN"", ""VB"", ""NN"", ""VB"", ""JJ"", ""NN"", ""VBN"", ""NN"", ""JJ""], [""NN"", ""RB"", ""VB"", ""JJS"", ""NN""], [""VB"", ""NN"", ""NN"", ""NNS""], [""JJ"", ""JJS"", ""NN"", ""NNS"", ""RB"", "":"", ""NN"", ""JJ"", ""JJ"", ""NN"", ""NNP""]]",right. watchword business restaurants included generally customer always right. especially true regard tastes appreciation flavors. people experience food way egotistic chef imagine right determine much salt put something ridiculous. chef n't know best everyone. keep salt pepper shakers. ubiquitous best flavor enhancers around -- reason ubiquitous good restaurant imho,"[""place"", ""table""]",place table,0,0;;;;

Clairette Rose,"I wonder how Ms Howell and others who insist it's their right to deny medical care to their children because they ""are committed to following in Christ Jesus' steps of relying on God's power alone for healing"" feel about others with different religious beliefs which dictate that they give their daughters in ""marriage"" to pedophile cult leaders, or who insist that their god requires that all girls be genitally mutilated according to the dictates of their belief system? We actually prosecute people who do such things. Why should a person who risks a child's life under the guise of a ""Christian"" belief be exempt? While enlightened people have existed for milennia, the Age of Reason officially began in the 18th century. When will we enter the 21st century?",parents ' religious beliefs,A4603-P,parents ' religious beliefs,0,1,1873,14382686,"[[""wonder"", ""ms"", ""howell"", ""others"", ""insist"", ""'s"", ""right"", Naphthous,"The most insightful writing to be found in almost any article occurs in the comments. Rarely is there a significant article that is neither debunked nor enhanced by the best of the comments. I have actually started checking whether comments are enabled before I read an article - and NOT reading it if they are disabled. To me, disabling comments is a sign of weakness and/or dishonesty on the part of the author and/or the publisher. It shows a fear of dissent, a fear of being scrutinized and/or challenged. Perhaps there is an underlying insecurity about not being viewed as an authoritative voice. The solution to repugnant comments isn't to ban all comments. The solution is mechanisms (which have existed for ages) that filter, sort, and hide comments at the pleasure of the user.",comment sections,A2782-P,comment SVA,"""Assuming an unpaid internship is mutually beneficial and entered into freely by both parties, should such arrangements be illegal? "" Just because we young people constitute a ""willing party"" when entering into an internship doesn't mean we are actually ""willing"". We simply have no choice. Ian Maitland,"A great idea that I have implemented in my own case over 5 or more years of commenting. Have I been called names? So what? I agree that it might be wise to permit exceptions. But I fear the exceptions would quickly begin to swallow the rule. I take anonymous comments less seriously than ones that disclose the poster's name -- though, granted, it is not always easy to tell them apart.",comment sections,A2771-P,comment sections,1,1,3791,18247268,"[[""great"", ""idea"", ""implemented"", ""case"", ""5"", ""years"", ""commenting""], [""called"", ""names""], [""agree"", ""might"", ""wise"", ""permit"", ""exceptions""], [""fear"", ""exceptions"", ""would"", ""quickly"", ""begin"", ""swallow"", ""rule""], [""take"", ""anonymous"", ""comments"", ""less"", ""seriously"", ""ones"", ""disclose"", ""poster"", ""'s"", ""name"", ""--"", ""though"", ""granted"", ""always"", ""easy"", ""tell"", ""apart""]]","[[""JJ"", ""NN"", ""VBN"", ""NN"", ""CD"", ""NNS"", ""VBG""], [""VBN"", ""NNS""], [""VBP"", ""MD"", ""JJ"", ""VB"", ""NNS""], [""VBP"", ""NNS"", ""MD"", ""RB"", ""VB"", ""VB"", ""NN""], [""VBP"", ""JJ"", ""NNS"", ""RBR"", ""RB"", ""NNS"", ""VBP"", ""NN"", ""POS"", ""NN"", "":"", ""RB"", ""VBN"", ""RB"", ""JJ"", ""VB"", ""RB""]]",great idea implemented case 5 years commenting. called names. agree might wise permit exceptions. fear exceptions would quickly begin swallow rule. take anonymous comments less seriously ones disclose poster 's name -- though granted always easy tell apart,"[""comment"", ""section""]",comment section,1,0;;;;

Steffan Piper,"How is bashing and belittling Amazon Publishing a debate? I fail to see anything more here than the usual 'let's smear Amazon because we must stay dogmatic about modern publishing.' Absolutely ridiculous. Referring to their editors as Chimpanzees is beyond low and trying to say that you're not is more than back-handed. And why must one automatically assume that they'll dominate the publishing industry -- especially if all they are interested in is widgets and algorithms? Inconsistent to say the least, especially if everyone else is so damn good. Seriously biased article and extremely flawed logic. If taking these kind of subtle but bratty gibes at Amazon makes someone feel better and gets them a few handshakes over their afternoon lunch in mid-town Manhattan, then I guess that's likely the real end result. Bashing someone for the sake of it is myopic at best and most reader's won't come away with anything but a negative point of view.",amazon,A311-P,amazon,1,1,15355,4757099,"[[""bashing"", Koyote,"The late Edward Abbey had a novel idea: allow anyone into a national park if travelling under their own steam -- walking, biking, skiing, etc. After all, getting out of the car is the best way to enjoy nature. As for the understandable complaints about children and the elderly not being able to travel in our parks under such a rule, Abbey replied that the kids will have their chances later (and we'll have preserved the parks for them), and the elderly had their chances when younger.",restricted access,A2961-P,restricted access,1,1,10248,18693740,"[[""late"", ""edward"", ""abbey"", ""novel"", ""idea"", ""allow"", ""anyone"", ""national"", ""park"", ""travelling"", ""steam"", ""--"", ""walking"", ""biking"", ""skiing"", ""etc""], [""getting"", ""car"", ""best"", ""way"", ""enjoy"", ""nature""], [""understandable"", ""complaints"", ""children"", ""elderly"", ""able"", ""travel"", ""parks"", ""rule"", ""abbey"", ""replied"", ""kids"", ""chances"", ""later"", ""'ll"", ""preserved"", ""parks"", ""elderly"", ""chances"", ""younger""]]","[[""JJ"", ""NNP"", ""NNP"", ""JJ"", ""NN"", ""VB"", ""NN"", ""JJ"", ""NN"", ""VBG"", ""NN"", "":"", ""VBG"", ""NN"", ""NN"", ""FW""], [""VBG"", ""NN"", ""JJS"", ""NN"", ""VB"", ""NN""], [""JJ"", ""NNS"", ""NNS"", ""JJ"", ""JJ"", ""VB"", ""NNS"", ""NN"", ""NNP"", ""VBD"", ""NNS"", ""NNS"", ""RB"", ""MD"", ""VBN"", ""NNS"", ""JJ"", ""NNS"", ""JJR""]]",late edward abbey novel idea allow anyone national park travelling steam -- walking biking skiing etc. getting car best way enjoy nature. understandable complaints children elderly able travel parks rule abbey replied kids chances later 'll preserved parks elderly chances younger,"[""restricted"", ""access""]",restricted access,1,0;;;;

Teresa Monroe,"Having access to videos of depositions that are also stenographically transcribed, I have seen firsthand that the human error rate is high. But why wouldn't it be? There are not many of us who have the concentration level to type precisely what people say for hours and hours at a time. Recordings are accurate, but the problem is that in order to cite them in a brief, they must be stenographically transcribed.",court stenographers,A4632-P,court stenographers,0,1,329,11525742,"[[""access"", ""videos"", ""depositions"", ""also"", ""stenographically"", ""transcribed"", ""seen"", ""firsthand"", ""human"", ""error"", ""rate"", ""high""], [""would"", ""n't""], [""many"", ""us"", ""concentration"", ""level"", ""type"", ""precisely"", ""people"", ""say"", ""hours"", ""hours"", ""time""], [""recordings"", ""accurate"", ""problem"", ""order"", ""cite"", ""brief"", ""must"", ""stenographically"", ""transcribed""]]","[[""NN"", ""NNS"", ""NNS"", ""RB"", ""RB"", ""VBN"", ""VBN"", ""RB"", ""JJ"", ""NN"", ""NN"", ""JJ""], [""MD"", ""RB""], [""JJ"", ""PRP"", ""NN"", ""NN"", ""VB"", ""RB"", ""NNS"", ""VBP"", ""NNS"", ""NNS"", ""NN""], [""NNS"", ""JJ"", ""NN"", ""NN"", ""VB"", ""NN"", ""MD"", ""RB"", ""VBN""]]",access videos depositions also stenographically transcribed seen firsthand human error rate high. would n't. many us concentration level type precisely people say hours hours time. recordings accurate problem order cite brief must stenographically transcribed,"[""court"", ""stenographer""]",court stenographer,0,0;;;;
S.L.,"It is impossible to get a good sampling from polls. Poll takers are like telemarketers;" they invade the privacy of our homes
post: especially when we are busiest. If I answer the phone at all
ori_topic: I am apt to be less than polite to the person who is bothering me. I have strong political opinions but the poll takers will never hear them because I don't want to answer a stranger's probing questions. What kinds of people are being sampled? I am not alone in my feelings about intrusive phone calls
ori_id: so it is none of us. Although I have had a few illegal calls on my cell phone
new_topic: those without landlines are not included in most samples. The skewed sampling is giving greater weight to the candidate whose fans are willing to be bothered by a poll. What does that say about his qualifications for the job of president? Nothing.""

author: asher,"Why are the Euro-zone members so reluctant to call it quits? It was a noble experiment, it had to be tried, but it failed miserably. Why keep punishing ordinary Europeans in order to save a fatally flawed idea? Let it go. Each country must return to individual currencies. Not doing so will lead to greater and greater misery which in turn will lead to violence and loss of life. It's not worth it. Time to admit that the elite economists and politicians failed Europe. Now the people of Europe must take back their lives. Get rid of the Euro and all the hateful feelings it has engendered in what had been a remarkably peaceful and prosperous group of nations.",germany,A3157-P,the euro,0,2,7734,7644790,"[[""euro"", ""zone"", ""members"", ""reluctant"", ""call"", ""quits""], [""noble"", ""experiment"", ""tried"", ""failed"", ""miserably""], [""keep"", ""punishing"", ""ordinary"", ""europeans"", ""order"", ""save"", ""fatally"", ""flawed"", ""idea""], [""let"", ""go""], [""country"", ""must"", ""return"", ""individual"", ""currencies""], [""lead"", ""greater"", ""greater"", ""misery"", ""turn"", ""lead"", ""violence"", ""loss"", ""life""], [""'s"", ""worth""], [""time"", ""admit"", ""elite"", ""economists"", ""politicians"", ""failed"", ""europe""], [""people"", ""europe"", ""must"", ""take"", ""back"", ""lives""], [""get"", ""rid"", ""euro"", ""hateful"", ""feelings"", ""engendered"", ""remarkably"", ""peaceful"", ""prosperous"", ""group"", ""nations""]]","[[""NNP"", ""NN"", ""NNS"", ""JJ"", ""VB"", ""VBZ""], [""JJ"", ""NN"", ""VBN"", ""VBD"", ""RB""], [""VB"", ""VBG"", ""JJ"", ""NNPS"", ""NN"", ""VB"", ""RB"", ""JJ"", ""NN""], [""VB"", ""VB""], [""NN"", ""MD"", ""VB"", ""JJ"", ""NNS""], [""VB"", ""JJR"", ""JJR"", ""NN"", ""NN"", ""VB"", ""NN"", ""NN"", ""NN""], [""VBZ"", ""JJ""], [""NN"", ""VB"", ""JJ"", ""NNS"", ""NNS"", ""VBD"", ""NNP""], [""NNS"", ""NNP"", ""MD"", ""VB"", ""RB"", ""NNS""], [""VB"", ""VBN"", ""NNP"", ""JJ"", ""NNS"", ""VBN"", ""RB"", ""JJ"", ""JJ"", ""NN"", ""NNS""]]",euro zone members reluctant call quits. noble experiment tried failed miserably. keep punishing ordinary europeans order save fatally flawed idea. let go. country must return individual currencies. lead greater greater misery turn lead violence loss life. DavGreg,"No two people have the same sense of taste nor does any one person have a consistent sense of taste given variables such as response to environmental allergies and recovery from colds. To say that salt is not offered at the table is Bloomberg Nannyish at minimum and downright control freakish. I long ago sought to reduce the salt in my diet and my taste has adjusted over time, but I have not eliminated salt nor do I intend to. Most baked or roasted poultry dishes are horrible without some added salt and there are other foods that cry out for it- popcorn is a good example. Having worked in healthcare for 27 years I have no illusions about the harm that a high sodium diet can have on some people. However, it is also possible to wisely reduce salt intake and still enjoy it in some foods. As the taste is highly subjective and individual I cannot agree with Mr Sbragg.",salt,A1791-P,salt,1,1,874,9944695,"[[""two"", ""people"", ""sense"", ""taste"", ""one"", ""person"", ""consistent"", Patricia,Only someone from a well-off family can afford to work for no pay. These unpaid internships harm the cause of social mobility. Social mobility is what keeps democracy and America strong. The possibility of forward movement what keeps Americans invested in the American dream. So I'm really against these internships in general. I applaud any means of preventing the already-rich from colonizing all the good careers in this country.,unpaid intenship,A448-P,unpaid intenship,0,1,16343,5449342,"[[""someone"", ""well"", ""family"", ""afford"", ""work"", ""pay""], [""unpaid"", ""internships"", ""harm"", ""cause"", ""social"", ""mobility""], [""social"", ""mobility"", ""keeps"", ""democracy"", ""america"", ""strong""], [""possibility"", ""forward"", ""movement"", ""keeps"", ""americans"", ""invested"", ""american"", ""dream""], [""'m"", ""really"", ""internships"", ""general""], [""applaud"", ""means"", ""preventing"", ""already"", ""rich"", ""colonizing"", ""good"", ""careers"", ""country""]]","[[""NN"", ""RB"", ""NN"", ""VB"", ""VB"", ""NN""], [""JJ"", ""NNS"", ""VBP"", ""NN"", ""JJ"", ""NN""], [""JJ"", ""NN"", ""VBZ"", ""NN"", ""NNP"", ""JJ""], [""NN"", ""JJ"", ""NN"", ""VBZ"", ""NNPS"", ""VBD"", ""JJ"", ""NN""], [""VBP"", ""RB"", ""NNS"", ""JJ""], [""VBP"", ""NNS"", ""VBG"", ""RB"", ""JJ"", ""VBG"", ""JJ"", ""NNS"", ""NN""]]",someone well family afford work pay. unpaid internships harm cause social mobility. social mobility keeps democracy america strong. possibility forward movement keeps americans invested american dream. John,"I agree with much of Bishop's comments. Polls track reactions to questions rather than opinions about society. That said, this is also how our political system works;" politicians speak in bumper-stickable clichÃ©s
post: provide little if any rationale for their positions
ori_topic: and ultimately voters enter a booth to poke a hole in a piece of paper. There is no national conversation.""
label: pollings

author: lloydmi,"Without open comment, I rarely any longer bother to read the article. Unlike Jamilla, I always check the comments first to see whether the article will be exciting. JMO,"What needs to happen is that insitutions of higher learning need to develop standards for internships. This should include a limit to the number of unpaid hours a worker can work in a week without triggering automatic compensation. Also companies should agree to interns representing only 5% of their workforce. The dirty little secret is that some companies are relying extensively on internships as a labor source. One of those companies is Disney, which has a good portion of its theme park workforce filled by interns. Then there must be standards for the work, flipping burgers or waiting tables are not acceptable intern experiences for college graduates.",unpaid intenship,A496-P,unpaid David Illig,"I can't think of a reason for the Queen to abdicate her solemn responsibilities. Should she become incapacitated the Privy Council has a mechanism for naming a regent. Charles should refuse the throne.. Nobody likes him. Of course, the British monarchy has evolved greatly over the past millennium or so, but historically, the monarch would have just as likely to have murdered or exiled the heir as to abdicate in his or her favor.",queen elizabeth ii,A2902-P,queen elizabeth ii,1,1,3616,9559686,"[[""ca"", ""n't"", ""think"", ""reason"", ""queen"", ""abdicate"", ""solemn"", ""responsibilities""], [""become"", ""incapacitated"", ""privy"", ""council"", ""mechanism"", ""naming"", ""regent""], [""charles"", ""refuse"", ""throne"", "".."", ""nobody"", ""likes""], [""course"", ""british"", ""monarchy"", ""evolved"", ""greatly"", ""past"", ""millennium"", ""historically"", ""monarch"", ""would"", ""likely"", ""murdered"", ""exiled"", ""heir"", ""abdicate"", ""favor""]]","[[""MD"", ""RB"", ""VB"", ""NN"", ""NNP"", ""VB"", ""JJ"", ""NNS""], [""VB"", ""VBN"", ""NNP"", ""NNP"", ""NN"", ""VBG"", ""NN""], [""NNP"", ""VB"", ""NN"", ""."", ""NN"", ""VBZ""], [""RB"", ""JJ"", ""NN"", ""VBN"", ""RB"", ""JJ"", ""NN"", ""RB"", ""NN"", ""MD"", ""JJ"", ""VBN"", ""VBN"", ""NN"", ""VB"", ""NN""]]",ca n't think reason queen abdicate solemn responsibilities. become incapacitated privy council mechanism naming regent. charles refuse throne .. nobody likes. course british monarchy evolved greatly past millennium historically monarch would likely murdered exiled heir abdicate favor,"[""queen"", ""elizabeth"", ""ii""]",queen elizabeth ii,0,0;;;;

Joe Cigliano,"there is no room for debate. Police in the United Staes have shot and killed more people in the month of March, than police in Great Briton have shot and killed in the last 100 years. Don't bother trying to correct for demographics, there is no way to make this fact correct. It just can't be squared. Police in the U.S. Have been taught it is OK to kill someone in there own defense, it is not. It is always murder when you take a life, and should always be investigated as murder. If you want balance, then every one who shoots some one, police or not, should be charged with murder, and investigated from that perspective. There should be no special rules for police or not.",police,A4464-P,police,0,1,11699,14673545,"[[""room"", ""debate""], [""police"", ""united"", ""staes"", ""shot"", ""killed"", ""people"", ""month"", ""march"", ""police"", ""great"", ""briton"", ""shot"", ""killed"", ""last"", ""100"", ""years""], [""n't"", ""bother"", ""trying"", ""correct"", ""demographics"", ""way"", ""make"", ""fact"", ""correct""], [""ca"", ""n't"", ""squared""], [""police"", ""u.s."", ""taught"", ""ok"", ""kill"", ""someone"", ""defense""], [""always"", ""murder"", ""take"", ""life"", ""always"", ""investigated"", ""murder""], [""want"", ""balance"", ""every"", ""one"", ""shoots"", ""one"", ""police"", ""charged"", ""murder"", ""investigated"", ""perspective""], [""special"", ""rules"", ""police""]]","[[""NN"", ""NN""], [""NNS"", ""NNP"", ""NNP"", ""VBN"", ""VBD"", ""NNS"", ""NN"", ""NNP"", ""NNS"", ""NNP"", ""NNP"", ""VBN"", ""VBN"", ""JJ"", ""CD"", ""NNS""], [""RB"", ""VB"", ""VBG"", ""VB"", ""NNS"", ""NN"", ""VB"", ""NN"", ""JJ""], [""MD"", ""RB"", ""VBN""], [""NNS"", ""NNP"", ""VBN"", ""JJ"", ""VB"", ""NN"", ""NN""], [""RB"", ""NN"", ""VBP"", ""NN"", ""RB"", ""VBN"", ""NN""], [""VBP"", ""NN"", ""DT"", ""NN"", ""VBZ"", ""CD"", ""NNS"", ""VBN"", ""NN"", ""VBN"", ""NN""], [""JJ"", ""NNS"", ""NN""]]",room debate. police united staes shot killed people month march police great briton shot killed last 100 years. n't bother trying correct demographics way make fact correct. ca n't squared. police u.s. taught ok kill someone defense. always murder take life always investigated murder. want balance every one shoots one police charged murder investigated perspective. special rules police,"[""police""]",police,1,1;;;;

Virginia Beck, NP, CTP,"As a five year old, I watched the young Queen take up royal duties, after the death of her beloved father. In 1953, her government was still struggling with the aftermath of the wholesale destruction and devastation of Britain and the loss of a whole generation of young men....Governing a country is no easy task. It ignores the facts to imply that all she knows is horses. Having lived through some of the more catastrophic changes on this planet, political as well as economic and personal;" bringing a country back from the ruins
post: and having been forced to make some very tough decisions
ori_id: not just a few paragraphs... Her Royal Highness
label: more wisdom than all journalists combined.""
column140: five year old watched young queen take royal duties death beloved father. 1953 government still struggling aftermath wholesale destruction devastation britain loss whole generation young men .... governing country easy task. ignores facts imply knows horses. lived catastrophic changes planet political well economic personal bringing country back ruins forced make tough decisions impact millions people paragraphs .... royal highness probably wisdom journalists combined

author: DLH,"In fact, the research on this point is now more in favor of salt than against it. And for people not near the coast, the iodine in salt is necessary to prevent goiter. I go to a lot of restaurants these day where there's hot sauce on the tables and people douse their food with so much that I wonder how they can taste anything. That's their choice;" if salt is mine
post: then supply the salt. Restaurants are supposed to be about cooks serving the customers
ori_topic: not about those who are paying bowing to the 'vision' of the 'chef.'""
label: salt
column97: fact research point favor salt. people near coast iodine salt necessary prevent goiter. go lot restaurants day 's hot sauce tables people douse food much wonder taste anything. 's choice salt mine supply salt. restaurants supposed cooks serving customers paying bowing vision chef

Emile,"Muslim women blathering on about solidarity, or the feminism implied by the head scarf, or whatever, are of course free to blather on. But to wear the head scarf here, in Western society, sends this message to people like me: ""I do not value, or want to value, the meaning of Western culture's freedoms. By wearing my head scarf in this public space we share, I declare first and foremost that I am a Muslim, and that I am different from you."" Thought: What if we all went about wearing funny hats declaring our religious allegiances? Wouldn't that be the end of any idea of a shared public space? P.S. Mary Wollstonecraft must be rolling over in her grave.",non-muslims,A2620-P,non-muslims,1,1,16560,17143445,"[[""muslim"", ""women"", ""blathering"", ""solidarity"", ""feminism"", ""implied"", ""head"", ""scarf"", ""whatever"", ""course"", ""free"", ""blather""], [""wear"", ""head"", ""scarf"", ""western"", ""society"", ""sends"", ""message"", ""people"", ""like"", ""value"", ""want"", ""value"", ""meaning"", ""western"", ""culture"", ""'s"", ""freedoms""], [""wearing"", ""head"", ""scarf"", ""public"", ""space"", ""share"", ""declare"", ""first"", ""foremost"", ""muslim"", ""different""], [""thought"", ""went"", ""wearing"", ""funny"", ""hats"", ""declaring"", ""religious"", ""allegiances""], [""would"", ""n't"", ""end"", ""idea"", ""shared"", ""public"", ""space""], [""p.s.""], [""mary"", ""wollstonecraft"", ""must"", ""rolling"", ""grave""]]","[[""JJ"", ""NNS"", ""VBG"", ""NN"", ""NN"", ""VBN"", ""NN"", ""NN"", ""WDT"", ""NN"", ""JJ"", ""NN""], [""VB"", ""NN"", ""NN"", ""JJ"", ""NN"", ""VBZ"", ""NN"", ""NNS"", ""IN"", ""VB"", ""VBP"", ""VB"", ""NN"", ""JJ"", ""NN"", ""POS"", ""NNS""], [""VBG"", ""NN"", ""NN"", ""JJ"", ""NN"", ""VBP"", ""VBP"", ""RB"", ""RB"", ""NNP"", ""JJ""], [""NN"", ""VBD"", ""VBG"", ""JJ"", ""NNS"", ""VBG"", ""JJ"", ""NNS""], [""MD"", ""RB"", ""NN"", ""NN"", ""VBN"", ""JJ"", ""NN""], [""NNP""], [""NNP"", ""NNP"", ""MD"", ""VBG"", ""NN""]]",muslim women blathering solidarity feminism implied head scarf whatever course free blather. wear head scarf western society sends message people like value want value meaning western culture 's freedoms. wearing head scarf public space share declare first foremost muslim different. thought went wearing funny hats declaring religious allegiances. would n't end idea shared public space. p.s.. mary wollstonecraft must rolling grave,"[""nonmuslim""]",nonmuslim,0,0;;;;

David Chowes,"In my seven decades living in this nation, I'll bet that over a hundred of books on dieting have appeared on the New York Times bestseller list of books. Forgetabout them! To lose weight is a lifetime goal. All one needs is motivation and to realize that if you lose your X pounds, you have accomplished very little. One must change your eating behahiors permentally. And, don't forget the importance of exercise. If you have one or more dinners counter to your new eating behavior, don't use that as an excuse for going back to one's 'bad old ways.' Expect it and just realizee that it happened... And immediatly resume your healthy eating pattern. So, you like creamy cheese cake, chocolate, a rare prime sirloin steak... Have them -- infrequently and in moderation. There was a book by a Dr. Tarnow: ""The Scarsdale Diet.' It sold a zillion copies and brought the physician fame and fortune. It also caused his death. So, don't say I didn't warn you.",more advice,A1297-P,healthy eating,1,2,19412,6002325,"[[""seven"", ""decades"", ""living"", ""nation"", ""'ll"", ""bet"", ""hundred"", ""books"", ""dieting"", Richard Mitchell-Lowe,"The New York Times has it right. A moderated comments facility provides immense value to readers seeking to understand the considered views of fellow human beings. Understanding the interests of others and seeking sensible consensus and compromise is one of the key foundations of a democracy. In times of bleak news, the NY Times comments pages provide a heartbeat of global perspective that reminds one the world is full of good, interested and decent people who care enough to speak out.",comment sections,A2795-P,comment sections,1,1,649,18249368,"[[""new"", ""york"", ""times"", ""right""], [""moderated"", ""comments"", ""facility"", ""provides"", ""immense"", ""value"", ""readers"", ""seeking"", ""understand"", ""considered"", ""views"", ""fellow"", ""human"", ""beings""], [""understanding"", ""interests"", ""others"", ""seeking"", ""sensible"", ""consensus"", ""compromise"", ""one"", ""key"", ""foundations"", ""democracy""], [""times"", ""bleak"", ""news"", ""ny"", ""times"", ""comments"", ""pages"", ""provide"", ""heartbeat"", ""global"", ""perspective"", ""reminds"", ""one"", ""world"", ""full"", ""good"", ""interested"", ""decent"", ""people"", ""care"", ""enough"", ""speak""]]","[[""NNP"", ""NNP"", ""NNP"", ""JJ""], [""JJ"", ""NNS"", ""NN"", ""VBZ"", ""JJ"", ""NN"", ""NNS"", ""VBG"", ""VB"", ""VBN"", ""NNS"", ""JJ"", ""JJ"", ""NNS""], [""VBG"", ""NNS"", ""NNS"", ""VBG"", ""JJ"", ""NN"", ""NN"", ""CD"", ""JJ"", ""NNS"", ""NN""], [""NNS"", ""JJ"", ""NN"", ""NNP"", ""NNP"", ""VBZ"", ""NNS"", ""VBP"", ""NN"", ""JJ"", ""NN"", ""VBZ"", ""CD"", ""NN"", ""JJ"", ""JJ"", ""JJ"", ""JJ"", ""NNS"", ""VBP"", ""RB"", ""VB""]]",new york times right. moderated comments facility provides immense value readers seeking understand considered views fellow human beings. understanding interests others seeking sensible consensus compromise one key foundations democracy. times bleak news ny times comments pages provide heartbeat global perspective reminds one world full good interested decent people care enough speak,"[""comment"", ""section""]",comment section,1,0;;;;

Mike,"I fully agree with everything you've said and would like to add one further point which comes to mind after having recently observed a proceeding in New York Supreme Court in Manhattan. There was a court reporter at work on that case along with an audio system for the benefit of those in the courtroom. Their juxtaposition had me thinking about the need for both several times throughout the day, and I concluded that the audio system would do just fine on its own -- so long as the participants are reminded to speak clearly enough for recording. There were times when I was pretty sure that the judge was relying on the court reporter's good sense of hearing to make a complete transcript and may not herself have heard everything that was said. So, even if court reporters are someday replaced by recording devises, they may still be needed to act as recoding engineers of sorts to ensure a faithful transcription.",court Distantly Related,"Libraries are a place for word literate people to visit in the increasingly computer literate wasteland. In a world where we are increasingly ROTFL and LMAO in twitterese or emailese (sorry to make up these proto-language names), some people just want to read a book while surrounded by other books. We want to check them out of the library and bring them back and repeat the process. We are still in love with the comfort of the printed page on paper. If all you are using it for is computer access, stop. Get a cheap android tablet, go to McDonalds, buy lunch and a coffee, get the password from the manager and surf away. Next time you are there, sit in the browsing section and read something other than your electronic reader.",libraries,A1591-P,libraries,1,1,18262,7952064,"[[""libraries"", ""place"", ""word"", B.A.,"RateMyTeacher.com, a corollary to RateMyProfessor.com, brings out the crazies and the malcontents. Over the past 12-15 years, the comments posted about me are often by disturbed students. Three times I've had to write the site to dispute a student's comments: One who said I knew nothing (I'd written a book on the subject), one who wrote because he was disgruntled about the way I tried to differentiate tests (mandated by the school), and another who commented that I was depressed (far from the truth) -- whom I doubt was even my student! I think the site is dangerous and invites trolling by students with severe misconceptions, those unhappy about grades, and those with gripes that would be better expressed in a face to face discussion. These posted comments affect a teacher's reputation and ability to find another job. I dread looking at the site to see what's there -- but on the other hand, I do look to see if there are comments that need to be removed because they are vicious or false.",rate ellen,"Most restaurant food is already too salty. I'd rather they salted their food LESS and let us control our salt at the table. I don't use table salt, myself. I lightly season my food and then if others want more salt they can have it. Salt should be treated as an adjunct. Food should be seasoned with spices. The salt is there to increase those flavors, not to be a flavor in and of itself. DemocracyNow,"This lack of pay is not limited to high school or college internships. It is found throughout the business world. People are encouraged to blog for a major media organization not for pay, but for ""the exposure,"" only to see that media organization sold to another company for hundreds of millions of dollars. Workers age 50 and over, who still have much to contribute, are thrown out of jobs in a subtle form of age discrimination and are then expected to work for free as part of their ""retraining"" to ease into a new profession that might pay thousands less in the end. Another poster on here mentioned volunteer workers who put in long hours while the heads of those charities reap huge salaries and benefits. The trend toward free labor is another indication of our moral decline. We have to take a stand. People, when you get up tomorrow morning and look at yourself in the mirror, repeat these words: ""I WILL NOT work for free.""",college students,A473-P,college students,1,1,9179,5449426,"[[""lack"", Margaret,"I have had 7 cats over the past 25  years--all rescues. I don't adopt kittens, only cats that are more than 9 months old, simply because there are so many adult cats who are surrendered. I have tried, with each cat, to train them to use a scratching post, put aluminum foil on couch arms, etc etc. NOTHING has worked (and being older cats, they were not amenable to having their nails clipped). All that banning declawing will do is force more and more cats into shelters. My cats have had no litter box issues, no aggression issues, and frankly, while I wouldn't declaw a cat older than 5 yrs, I have no guilt in declawing a young adult cat that then is an indoor-only pet. I understand it is painful but it is certainly less horrible than abandonment, the stress of being surrendered to a shelter (and really, there is a very low chance in many states for that adult cat to be adopted), and/or euthanasia.",your cat,A866-P,declawing cats,1,2,12933,17012435,"[[""7"", ""cats"", ""past"", ""25"", "" "", ""years"", ""--"", ""rescues""], [""n't"", ""adopt"", ""kittens"", dbrea2000,"Reality check for those so far removed that have no idea what the issue is: Women come to the U.S. on temp visas or illegally to give birth in order to have the child become an American citizen. In some cases they stay, and in others they leave with the American child. Those that leave will eventually reap the benefits of American citizenship without ever contributing to it. It's become status symbol for foreign nationals to have children with the blue and gold passport. This is reality;" and I'm sure the founding fathers didn't have this in mind when the constitution was adopted.""
post: birthright citizenship
column115: reality check far removed idea issue women come u.s. temp visas illegally give birth order child become american citizen. cases stay others leave american child. leave eventually reap benefits american citizenship without ever contributing. 's become status symbol foreign nationals children blue gold passport. reality 'm sure founding fathers n't mind constitution adopted

author: ejzim,"First, I'd like to point out that the original question makes no sense. The behavior is aberrant, not the murder charges. However, I'm sure those of us who object to the aberrant behavior of our police forces surmise that events, like this one, have happened thousands of times, all over this country, without video evidence. Yes, there should be a federal database that goes back, in time, to at least the 1964 Civil Rights Act.",police,A4446-P,police,1,1,4247,14663382,"[[""first"", ""'d"", ""like"", ""point"", ""original"", ""question"", ""makes"", ""sense""], [""behavior"", ""aberrant"", ""murder"", ""charges""], [""however"", ""'m"", ""sure"", ""us"", ""object"", ""aberrant"", ""behavior"", ""police"", ""forces"", ""surmise"", ""events"", ""like"", ""one"", ""happened"", ""thousands"", ""times"", ""country"", ""without"", ""video"", ""evidence""], [""yes"", ""federal"", ""database"", ""goes"", ""back"", ""time"", ""least"", ""1964"", ""civil"", ""rights"", ""act""]]","[[""RB"", ""MD"", ""VB"", ""VB"", ""JJ"", ""NN"", ""VBZ"", ""NN""], [""NN"", ""NN"", ""NN"", ""NNS""], [""RB"", ""VBP"", ""JJ"", ""PRP"", ""VBP"", ""NN"", ""NN"", ""NN"", ""NNS"", ""NN"", ""NNS"", ""IN"", ""NN"", ""VBN"", ""NNS"", ""NNS"", ""NN"", ""IN"", ""NN"", ""NN""], [""UH"", ""JJ"", ""NN"", ""VBZ"", ""RB"", ""NN"", ""JJS"", ""CD"", ""NNP"", ""NNPS"", ""NNP""]]",first 'd like point original question makes sense. behavior aberrant murder charges. however 'm sure us object aberrant behavior police forces surmise events like one happened thousands times country without video evidence. yes federal database goes back time least 1964 civil rights act,"[""police""]",police,1,1;;;;

Mathias Weitz,"The system is out of balance, and it's the national industries with their very different output levels which thrives this diversion. There is a lot of tax-payer money which is trying to counter this, but the money, which is on account of the governments are just peanuts. The german industry is steamrolling the rest of europe, and for this devastation everyone has to pay, first of all the german tax-payers. Just look at france, their demise is now on the lever. Where should this end ? A few countries with a workforce of 50 Mio is liable for producing the need of 350 Mio citizen ? But the main problem are political and social issues. This is a conundrum, the moral hazard - unlike the US every country is liable for their own efficiency. Germany can try to drag along the rest of europe, but one reason for a success is our global competitiveness and we may fail to maintain this - to say the european economy as whole has rightly become global insignificant.",germany,A3155-P,germany,1,1,3189,7638757,"[[""system"", ""balance"", ""'s"", ""national"", ""industries"", ""different"", ""output"", ""levels"", ""thrives"", ""diversion""], DoritReiss,"It's heartbreaking to think of children suffering because of denial of treatment - or protection against disease - from a religion they did not choose. Judyw,"I have bought organic food and have never noticed that it tasted any better than the non-organic variety. I just paid more for it. Steven,"With all due respect, Judge Kopf, digital recording technology cannot capture when somebody is not speaking loud enough, clear enough, or speaks with a thick accent. Don P.,"Simply said the Queen is not going to step down. Upon ascending to the throne she made a vow to serve her people until her death. Words and the people who spoke them truly meant something at that time and still do to people of her generation. Queen Elizabeth came to the throne during a very difficult period for her people and the world and she helped lead her nation from those days to today always as a constant source of pride and inspiration. And it appears that the qualities that made her a loved and inspirational leader skipped a generation bypassing her son, Charles, and now appears rooted in her grandson, William. Bob H,Rate my Professor is essentially an internet scam to generate site traffic. I am sorry to see it getting this kind of free publicity in a serious paper like the NYT. Rate my Professor is a for-profit site. You can even post a review of someone without ever having taken a class with that person or on a class that the professor never taught. Try it. Most universities have systems for the evaluation of faculty. (I would be surprised if any do not.) Sailor40,"Some people become addicted to alcohol, but after the fiasco of Prohibition, the United States learned that we were better off legalizing and controlling access to it. Gambling has been legalized in most states, and regardless of the current attempts to block it, Americans today already have access to Internet based gambling. The regulations that currently restrict the banking system from dealing with Internet gamling sites should be eliminated. Regulations should be established to protect consumers. The resulting legal activity should be taxed to pay for the necessary oversight agencies, and to provide assistance for those who can't simply enjoy gambling as entertainment and sport.",internet David Keys,"Most Americans have the same attitude about languages other than their own, as they have about those people who might speak them--fear [and eventually hate]...Although I was educated in what seems like the last ice age, instruction in foreign language began in earnest in middle school and graduating with a bachelor's degree required competency in both a classical (Latin, Greek, Hebrew) and a modern language (French, Spanish, or Italian). With all the teaching aids at our fingertips now, the old curriculum should be revived. pub,"Greece hasn't come to grips with the elites that have not only poisoned their country but ruined it. Syriza's defiance of the rest of Europe (though many countries in the south will try to emulate Greek intransigence) will be an enormous, even ultimate stress test for the European Union. elizabeth renant,"The only solidarity the hijab shows is with that most ancient of patriarchal male control strategies, shifting the burden of morality, family and male honor, etc., onto the shoulders of female modesty. It is no different from Orthodox Jewish married women having to cover their hair, or the in the Middle Ages married women in Europe were expected to wear a coif to cover their hair, and is nakedly an attempt to confine women's sexual nature in as small a space as possible. It stands in relationship to footbinding and to female genital mutilation, albeit at another point on the bellcurve of control of women and control of female sexuality. If you insist on sacrificing yourself on this altar to show ethnic solidarity, don't be surprised when people conclude that Islam is still stuck in the past. As Rhett Butler once famously said to Scarlett in ""Gone with the Wind"" when she refused to abandon black mourning clothes for a husband she not only didn't love, but despised, ""How closely women clutch the chains that bind them!"" Find another way to announce your religious/ethnic identity. Your daughters deserve a better message.",non-muslims,A2614-P,religious/ethnic identity,0,2,6428,17141541,"[[""solidarity"", ""hijab"", ""shows"", ""ancient"", ""patriarchal"", ""male"", ""control"",
